												The Witness is a game where you wander around an island solving cryptic puzzles. It's really good and I love it.I bought this game completely blind and my immediate first impressions were how breathtakingly beautiful the world is. Stepping out into the open of the island for the first time was a chilling experience. It's easily understandable why Jon Blow took so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ long to create this game. The design behind the game works so well. *[en.wikipedia.org]The actual puzzles wouldn't find themselves out of place in a free mobile puzzle game, but the island adds entire new dimensions to the solutions. The answers are integrated into the environment in a surprisingly varying number of ways. The deceivingly simple puzzles are kept fresh throughout. Sometimes, like a Metroidvania, a simple puzzle will be impossible to solve until you explore elsewhere and learn how to use the new mechanic, helping you further uncover the secrets of the world of The Witness.The game will never explicitly explain the mechanics of the puzzles to you. You are left to decipher the island on your own. I wish I could describe some of the ways you need to solve the puzzles in this game, but of course, that’d ruin the experience of finding it out for yourself and feeling like a genius. So just trust me. It’s an incredibly creative game.This is an easy choice my 2016 game of the year.Of course, this kind of game isn't for everybody, but if you have the slightest interest in the concept of 'wandering around an island solving cryptic puzzles' sounds interesting to you, I highly recommend The Witness.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Sometimes brilliant things come out of restrictions to a form. You can see them in some of the classic early video games, in art, and in film. In the Witness they decided very early on to restrict their puzzle to the basic panels you see in previews for the game, but the brilliance is in the way they've taken the idea to its absolute peak. The puzzles in this game are inventive, challenging, and somehow manage to be varied. If you're at all interested in subtle game design, The Witness is rich in undertones and manages to both effortlessly and wordlessly guide the player to solve extremely difficult puzzles.This game differs from other classic adventure puzzle games in that it is almost entirely distilled gameplay. There is little narrative carrying you along, and although there are voiced pieces in the game, most of them are about the human mind rather than any story. For the most part, the game leaves you to pull your own meaning out of it.The Witness is not for everyone. If you love puzzles for the sake of puzzles, I don't think you'll find a game with more challenging and clever puzzles than this game. The island, in its isolation, ambience, and beauty, is a solitary retreat. You could equate the experience of this game to sitting down with a sudoku puzzle at the kitchen table on a rainy Sunday morning, a cup of coffee to your right and raindrops pitter-patting against the window.

Exploration and PuzzlesDo you enjoy logic puzzles involving rules, patterns, symbols, geometric shapes, process of elimination, drawing lines, sudoku etc.? If you don't you can forget about The Witness, if you do then read on.If there ever was a game designed to be best experienced completely blind it's The Witness, so if you already have a strong feeling like this might be your kind of game, I'd recommend you to stop reading and go play it.I went in knowing nothing more than that it was some kind of puzzle game and I'm glad I did, but from a consumer perspective I think it's worth knowing that every single puzzle in the game is some sort of grid or node tree, where the solution is to draw a path through it according to the logic used in the particular puzzle.This means there's not a huge variety in the base type of puzzles, and the variety instead comes from the many different logic rules found throughout the game. It also gives the game a great sense of cohesion as a lot of it builds upon your previous understanding of the logic and virtually all of the rules can be used together to make new puzzle combinations.Exploration is also a big part of The Witness. Exploring the island, exploring for puzzles, exploring and learning the puzzle rules. The game is completely open—if you manage to figure out the rules of a puzzle on your own nothing stops you from progressing—and there's very little handholding.That's not to say the game is obscure or unfair, on the contrary all of the rules have great introductions, but the progression isn't linear so just because you come across a puzzle doesn't necessarily mean you're supposed to know how to solve it. If you get stuck it's better to explore in a different direction and come back later, maybe you'll have a better understanding of the rules, or maybe you'll notice something you didn't the first time.This is where a bit of a gameplay issue comes in, in that there's no real map or navigational system present most of the time. Some kind of in-game camera/snapshot function and maybe a simple map that allowed for notes would have been nice, now you'll have to make do with a pen, notebook and some grid paper (which I'd recommend having handy anyway for a few of the more advanced puzzles.)But the island isn't really all that big. My sense of direction is absolutely terrible, and I even I had no problem navigating after crossing it a couple of times. It does mean you'll be trekking back and forth a bit however, so I would advise against playing this if you're feeling pressed for time or find yourself wanting to rush through it, as you won't have a good time.The aesthetics of the game are gorgeous, and the technical aspects are pretty good. You can stand virtually anywhere on the island and look in any direction and get a colorful, picturesque, serene, postcard-worthy scenery. The game environments are all very well-designed too, often integrating cleverly with various puzzles or providing clues on how to solve a particular puzzle, and the island has plenty of landmarks and visual cues helpful for navigation.As for the story, there is none. There's plenty of curious and mysterious imagery on the the island, but you can only look and wonder and come up with your own theories, the game will tell you nothing. Scattered throughout are audio/video logs which are mostly thoughts and musings of various historical people on the topics of philosophy, religion and science. Interesting and thought-provoking, or just pretentious, depending on how you're inclined to feel.I would have loved something more conventional, a mystery unraveled along with with the puzzles, and although it's a fine game even without it, be aware that you'll mostly be puzzling for the puzzles' sake and exploring for exploration's sake, as there's little other reward for it. Considering this I would recommend not peeking at any guides or reading too much about it if you intend to play it, or it would all be rather pointless.Either way the beautiful environments, puzzle integration and the audio logs provide a great atmosphere and contemplating tone and elevates the experience to something much greater than what could have just been a series of IQ tests.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Before venturing into this game, I will warn you, as have many others by now, that this game has absolutely nothing to offer in terms of lore, story, characters, or any narrative elements to speak of.  This game is comprised solely of puzzles and explorations. That which it has, is done masterfully, but don't go in expecting it to be something it's not. The central core of the game is about learning. EVERYTHING in the game, every maze, every obstacle, even the environment is a constant and concerted effort to teach the player. The problem, at the start of the game, is that the player does not yet understand the language in which the game operates. So it is the task of the player to, essentially, learn how to learn. How to listen and how to read, to be open to new and challenging concepts, and how to apply them to the world around you. This is the central experience of the game, and it is done beautifully well. If you allow the game to teach you, and you put your mind to work at it, this is a game that can be, and very much should be, completed without outside help or guides, because of how important your sense of discovery and understanding is to the experience of the game. The landscapes of the island are gorgeous, and while the game does not have a soundtrack, the sounds of the natural world around you inspire a stronger atmosphere of introspection. The environments are varied and gorgeous, and the architecture is thoughtful and detailed. Every inch of the game screams with attention to detail, no space is wasted, nothing is without intent and purpose. Every aspect of the game works together to create a truly wondrous experience. Perhaps my only complaint about the game is that one or two smaller sections of puzzles felt like they progressed with a somewhat unfair / disappointing form of difficulty, that just felt cheap and unimaginative. However this was a very small and specific set of puzzles, and is not a complaint I had anywhere else. The "main path" of the game is about 20 hours long, for a game like this, I feel like it's a good length: enough to keep you engaged and challenged, but not so long it wears itself thin. In addition to the "main path" I've caught a lot of glimpses throughout my play of well-hidden additional content and hidden / optional puzzles, which, from other reviews I've read, could easily tack on another 20 hours for the particularly meticulous player. Overall, The Witness is easily one of the best puzzle games I have ever played, and certainly one of the most unique gaming experiences out there. I cannot recommend it highly enough to anyone who enjoys puzzles and thinking games.

												This is a great game, well worth the asking price -- there was more care and attention put into this than any recent AAA title that I can recall.The world is gorgeous and well put together as a cohesive whole. That said, I do have a couple bits of minor criticism for The Witness:  It isn't quite as mind bending as Braid was: the puzzle mechanism in that game (time manipulation) involved your entire perception, and the mechanic in this game simply isn't as immersive (although the environment is certainly more immersive). The end-game feels a bit tedious and on-rails as opposed to the rest of the game. It would have been nice to continue with the theme of exploration and discovery right up to the conclusion.

												I absolutely loved this game.Besides the devillishly difficult but enjoyable puzzles, the game is truly beautiful and there is much to look at and enjoy. There are tape and video recordings hidden around the island for you to find if you keep an eye open for them. They are filled with quotes about the ways in which different thought processes colour our view of the world, such as thoughts on Religion, the Scientific Method, Human Morality and the Art of Zen.I have now 'finished' the game, although there are still quite some puzzles out there I think I might have missed or have remained unsolved as you do not have to solve every puzzle to 'complete' the game. However, when starting out I cannot stress enough that you have to explore the whole island to be able to solve the mazes. In the first hours you are playing you might think that the puzzles you are encountering are truly impossible. This is because the rules of these puzzles only get explained in certain areas, so there are many puzzles you will encounter in the beginning that are way too advanced for you. The more you explore, the more you learn bit by bit, the more fun the game gets. At the end I was gleefully solving puzzles while backtracking to places I thought were impossible the first time around.In this day and age it is sometimes difficult to just stay in a moment and have the patience for more than a few minutes to truly look at the details of an object that is in essence an extremely simple thing (a maze), repeating this process over and over and over again, and then still coming up with new ways of solving the same object. It is very refreshing, like a deep cleaning of your brain.All in all, I came away from this game with the Zen-like experience which I believe the game was trying to impress upon its players. I think if people are willing to set aside their expectations they will find much to enjoy.

												A beautiful island of puzzles. That's all I would say if the puzzles were simply connecting a line from A to B, but it's not that simple and you need to figure out why. Do you know that feeling when you discover something is not working then you realise what you can do to solve the problem? The Witness delivers that feeling of intelligence in many different puzzles in many different variations like any good puzzle game. What makes The Witness one of the special puzzle games is that the puzzles meaningfully feel like they are a part of a grander scheme - because they are. The environment around the puzzles gives you clues on how  to solve each of the puzzles, and some are the puzzles are literally the environment itself. But most important, you are not collecting meaningless tokens, you are slowly unlocking the island itself. The Witness is a rare treat for puzzle gamers - we will have to wait many years before we get another game of this quality (nothing has been as good The Witness & Obduction in years). If you like puzzles then The Witness is a must buy. If you love exploring interesting new worlds, then I recommend you buy The Witness. And if you are impatient and don't like being confused then you should avoid The Witness.

This is a game not for everyone… I repeat this game is not for everyone! It is a puzzle game, but don't expect it to be a linear story like Portal 2 or Talos Principle. What to expect is an atmospheric mind bending puzzle game on an beautifully designed island. The only story you will find is through the architecture, props and tape recorders (the tapes are quotes that are philosophical, astronomical, that sort of thing.) The story is open ended and not told in a normal manner.Hand holding is something this game does not do, it was designed in a way to respect the player for being observant. Gameplay and visuals teach the player on how to progress through certain puzzles. Puzzles will be many variants of the line and block puzzle you see in the screenshots, trailers and gameplay. Now there will be sets of puzzles in certain areas where you have to solve in a row, those are the ones that will teach the player how to use puzzles. There will be different mechanics thrown in when you have learned a puzzle. There are some very challenging puzzles in this game that are logically and thoughtfully designed with such a simple concept. If some puzzles are too hard the player can just go do other ones, you are free to walk the unbeaten path. This sort of freedom is fantastic!This is a really good game and I highly recommend this game if you really like puzzle games. As I said before it's a different game compared to Portal 2 and Talos Principle. It is a game that is not going to appeal to everyone either. Edit: Forgot to mention that the graphics options are limited to High, Medium and Low, vsync and full screen. No resolution or FOV options. You can edit these in the .ini files. http://www.wsgf.org/dr/witness/en

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												The Witness is a puzzle game like no other I have played.  It bucks the trend not only by having no narrative, but also by having no direct explanation of any of the game mechanics.  Rather than painstakingly explaining everything as most games do, The Witness simply provides the information you need and lets you figure it out.  It's quite refreshing in an era of constant hint popups, control prompts, and hour-long tutorials.Now how does this work?  The Witness provides all the information you need, and even provides a set of tutorial puzzles for each main mechanic but it does not tell you how any of it works.  Half the challenge is figuring out how the mechanics work.  The game provides a near-constant feeling of satisfaction from figuring the puzzles out, barring a very small minority of puzzles.  I found many of the puzzles rather clever in their design, and I find it quite telling how superb the design is that I only ever felt frustrated in two spots in the entire game when I am normally frustrated very easily by difficult puzzles.Another large difference I see between The Witness and other puzzle games is in the design of the puzzles themselves.  Most games use very simple mechanics and combine them in increasingly complex and lengthy ways to increase difficulty.  I find that results in the major difficulty of the puzzles being simply thinking through all the steps, rather than any mechanical complexity.  The Witness, however, uses more and more complex mechanics, constantly modifying or introducing new ones, without unnecessarily increasing the size or complexity of the puzzles themselves.  The difficulty feels more natural and logical this way, rather than just trying to overload the player's brain with too many steps.The part that makes this all work and ties it all together is the puzzle interface itself.  Puzzles are presented on panels throughout the game world with an exceedingly simple goal: Draw a line from the starting point to the ending point through a grid.  Every puzzle has the same basic goal, and this simplicity tying every puzzle together gives the player a feeling of familiarity, even when confronted by completely new mechanics.Graphically the game is very impressive, especially considering how low detail the models and textures are.  It runs quite smoothly as well, barring a particular bug with my GPU that I've been working around and will hopefully be solved in the near future.  The island is beautiful and very colorful, with each zone having a distinctive style.  Sound effects are minimal, but fit their purpose well.  There is no music, which I was confused about at first but completely understand after playing the game.  I wasn't even tempted to play my own music while playing the game.  Any music would drastically alter the mood, and the game is so tightly designed, it felt like that would lessen the experience.There are two things about the game I dislike:- The first being a small number of puzzles that felt like they could not be solved with perception and logic alone, but required the use of external software to decipher.- The second being the story, or lack thereof.  While nearly everything in the game is very tightly thematically linked around the idea of opening your mind and learning new things, I thought that there should be some sort of explanation for the island itself, why you're there, and certain things non-puzzle-related that you find.  It's possible there's a well-hidden secret that has not yet been discovered that contains this, but nothing has been located to my knowledge.  I know that some people complain about the lack of narrative, but while I don't think it would fit the game to have an Elohim or GlaDOS watching over you the whole time, I would have liked a little bit of something to explain the world.  There does seem to be an attempt by the game but I found it very lacking and it raised even more questions.I'm not sure I've ever played such a well-designed game.  Everything fits, everything supports the rest of the design.  The amount of content is certainly worth the price, containing more than either The Talos Principle or Portal 2.  It's certainly an experience unlike any I've had before in a game and I hope that other developers, not just of puzzle games, can learn from this example.  I realize this game isn't for everybody, but I hope that most will enjoy it as much as I did.

												I finished the game. Not 100% but completed the endgame. 518 Panels solved +53 secrets. If I understand the black Pillars correctly there are probably over 50 secrets left. Probably also a few panels left but I solved everyone I found (except one, for which I need to study a good few hours more). But I have all the lasers.This game is about exploring an island and solving the panels. The panels exhibit various mechanics/rules. And when looking at a very complex panel you have no chance figuring the panel out. But there are easy panels of each mechanic distributed over the island, which offer you to understand the mechanic step by step. So when you come across a new mechanic you don't have the knowledge to solve for yet you got to come back later when you learned more.The game has at least 10 zones where a laser can be activated by most of the panels there. Many zones exhibit one mechanic that is deepened but often combined with other mechanics to produce more difficulty. In some zones you have to complete all puzzles to activate the laser in others you can solve either half of the puzzles. When you reached a certain number of lasers you can enter the endgame. The endgame is so difficult. There are no words that do justice on how ♥♥♥♥ing difficult it is. It felt like torture. And I only worked it out by trial and error. At this point you should have fully understood every mechanic and can apply it with all its tricks. But the puzzles in the endgame sometimes seem impossible to solve. So you just try and try until out of luck something works. And the endgame is a long zone with many puzzles and combined mechanics from the whole island. I am sure that not many players will complete the game. It is just insanity and you really got to have the will and patience for it. (if you are not good in logical and methodical thinking you are screwed)There is no story whatsoever in this game. There are recordings that can be played but only contain some pseudo intellectual jabbering that goes on your nerves. And the voice actors weren't very passionate about it. The game has very beautiful graphics and very good sound effects. But there is no soundtrack. So you can play your own relaxing music while playing the game and I strongly recommend to do so because otherwise you end up frustrated way too early. Would I recommend? Yes if anyone wants to perceive the experience of exploring mechanics and is ready to handle the difficulty and frustration that comes with it. Go for it.

												I would recommend ignoring the dozens of negative reviews from users with less than 2 hours played who were angling for a Steam refund- they are universally bad takes from folks who didn't even scratch the surface of the game. The complaints that the game could be in 2D, or that the envrionment is pointless are ill-founded and kind of comical having played further. Same goes to the reviewers who complained that the walk speed is too slow or that you can't jump. Running is the *only* instruction the game actually provides to you, and complaining about jumping is completely beside the point of the game. Don't get me started on the person who said that the puzzles are "badly placed"- the Metroidvania structure isn't that difficult to figure out. If you don't know what a symbol means, thats a hint to go elsewhere.What you'll get with The Witness is a clever spin on puzzle gaming where the game isn't necessarily about solving line mazes, but about learning the ever-expanding vocabulary that governs them. It feels very satisfying to learn these rules and apply them all by yourself, and its hard to ever truly feel stuck since you can easily take a break and change gears to try a different set of puzzles with a different set of rules.To those who complain that there isn't a big payoff at the end, or that there needs to be more story or some sort of motivation to continue playing: knowledge is its own reward.

Posted: March 10, 2016
												I haven't quite finished everything, but I have completed a very significant portion of the game without any guides. Not only does this succeed in being the most consistently mind-blowing game, I've ever played, it's also unique from any puzzle I have ever seen because it requires both inductive and deductive logic. All puzzle games, whether it's sudoku or portal, give you the rules up front and then just rely on you to make deductive steps to reach the solution. In The Witness, the rules of the puzzle are never given to you. It is up to you to inductively guess what the rules could be, abductively test your supposed rules, and then deductively solve the puzzle based on the info that you yourself have been able to gather. Because of this, I would not hesitate to say it is the most challenging puzzle game I have ever played. This in turn creates the largest temptation to use a guide or look for hints because we naturally associate "more challenging" with "less doable". This is, however; not the case. The game is just as doable as any puzzle game, and it facilitates the learning of all of the rules naturally. If you go for this game, do not bang your head against the same puzzle for more than a few minutes. The world is open, when you get stuck, explore. The answers are never all in the same place. The creator very cleverly draws parallels between the relationship of the player and the game world to the relationship between the scientist and his testable environment. Jonathan Blow's philosophy of what we need to know, what we can know, and what is useful to know is very profoundly expressed through the game, although I can't say I totally agree with his rather cynical philosophical outlook. Very enjoyable, one of a kind experience. If you are willing to allow yourself to legitimately struggle with the unknown, you will get so much out of this game.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												This game is hard, but it's very relaxing. The general ambiance is very peaceful, and I find that complimenting the game with some light orchestral music makes for the perfect experience. The key to enjoying this game is to view the panels not as a challenge, but as a lesson. They're not something to be conquered, they're something to be approached on their own terms and handled as one becomes ready.I don’t think that the development team is trying to show off how smart they all are, and how dumb everyone else is. The puzzles aren’t trying to beat you back and dissuade you, they’re enticing you with the opportunity to learn and to understand and to explore. Sometimes, they fail. Most of the time, they succeed.I think the decision to build the game without an engaging narrative is a bit of a double edged sword. On the one hand, I don't feel frustration from not being able to complete the puzzles fast enough to satisfy my narrative curiosity, which was a problem I sometimes had in Portal. I always wanted to hear what Glados had to say next, even more than I really cared about solving the puzzles, a conflict which often led to significant frustration. In The Witness, I don't have to worry about missing out on a captivating narrative, because as far as I can tell, there isn’t one.But, on the other hand, not having an engaging narrative means that this isn’t a game that I can sit and play for long periods of time, especially now that I’ve gotten far enough in that puzzles are taking more than 10 minutes to solve. Even with the music, I find my mind wandering and thinking of other things to do. I just try to take it one panel at a time and when I start getting bored I do something else. When I come back later, I’ve regained some energy and my curiosity and I can enjoy playing once more.Ultimately, I offer my cautious recommendation of this game. If you find that you don’t like it before your refund period expires, just go and get a refund. It won’t get any easier or significantly more engaging any time soon, and you’re better off finding something else that can hold your attention.

												The Witness is an unexpected journey to forgotten lands of your brain. Since the Portal and Portal 2, I have never been so amazed by overall theme and emotion of the whole game. It feels really as a whole, and not as a decoration for some puzzles and author's ideas. Basically, the game explores one mechanic. But creating new rules, then bending them over to create new rules, combining those rules in different, unimaginable at first, ways - all of this creates an atmosphere, where you are proud of your solutions, even the simplest ones. The game is hard sometimes. I mean, it isn't scary hard, but I had a couple of dozens of puzzles, which stopped me for some significant time. The difficulty in the game increases gradually, which is a big plus for such games. You don't want to stop, because you understand that every minute you spend in the game, you solve something a bit harder, you brain works a bit better, so you are... a lot smarter?There is one thing, where the game even beats Portal games. The environment here holds your attention, which wasn't the part of the game feel in Portal. Trees and sand, rocks and ocean, windmill and autumn leaves, sometimes you just stop and watch the nature of this island. There is more in it, sometimes you can find a small puzzle or secret in an unexpected place, sometimes the environment plays a significant role in puzzle solution and... sometimes the island is the puzzle itself. And in the end, the atmosphere and puzzles don't interfere, but work together to give you the game experience of the year. If there will be another puzzle game of such level, I would call it extraordinary year. P.S. DLC please? Please?

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												The witness is a divisive game to say the least. The people who like it, really like it. But those who go in expecting something this game is not, are almost certain to walk away disappointed. The following are just some general things about the game. I dare not call them "facts" since some things are still subjective, but I try.Whether you will like the Witness or nor depends largely on whether you consider any of the following to be pros or cons.1. A number of puzzles rely on color and sound, more so than you might be used to in other games. Colorblind or tone deaf players be warned.2. Similarly, there are a handful of puzzles with brightly flashing colors which may cause discomfort.3. The Witness is a puzzle game, far more than it is a puzzle-adventure game. It's not Myst. Solving puzzles doesn't give you a new piece of the story. It gives you more puzzles. Story is an afterthought at best.4. The witness has decent atmospheric sound design, but is devoid of almost any background music.5. Some sections you may do 10 or 20 puzzles in a row that are similar except for increasing complexity.6. This game has no tutorials, no hints. Everything is determined by the scientific method. You have to experiment with puzzles to understand how they work.7. When you solve a puzzle in the Witness, there is no fanfare, no sparkles, no gold star rating. For the most part, the only reward is unlocking the next puzzle.8. The Witness is open-world. You can very early in the game go nearly everywhere in the island. It is also likely to throw puzzles at you in the early game that you will need to step away from and come back to much later.9. You will always be drawing lines in this game. There are many different mechanics at work, which make for many unique puzzles, but the method of imputing the solution is always the same. Even switches and levers are line puzzles.10. This game can be really hard, obtuse, and often frustratingly mind-bending. Sometimes, very rarely, it might also be just a little cheap.- The bonus totally not objective sectionUnpopular opinion inbound, but I think I liked this more than The Talos Principle, to which it is compared quite a lot. I like the mental process of solving puzzles, but not really the act of having to show my work, which in Talos Principle might mean 5 to 10 minutes of carrying around boxes through force fields and trying to get a laser angle just right. I already know the answer. I don't want to have to do all the grunt work as well. I want to do a new puzzle.  This game allowed me to do just that. Once a puzzle clicked, it took just a few seconds to draw it out, and move on to the next challenge. This wasn't always true. At times the pace set by the puzzles is broken by the languid pace of the world around you, which I suppose is fine, if you are taking the game at a slow pace. Near the end of the game, getting around the island between the few puzzles you might have remaining was also not that much fun anymore, and one or two puzzles were maybe just a bit too obnoxious in the way it regarded my time.  Despite this, for the most part, I loved it. It this was one of the most inventive, original and gorgeous puzzle games I had played in a long time.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												An excercise in frustrationThere are key elements to first person puzzle games that The Witness simply does not have. As Portal and The Talos Principle if you add a story and/or humor to a puzzle game you make it seem less hard. While the player has fun laughing at Glados or is pondering the philosophical implications of The Talos principle, the brain gets a chance to relax. To gain perspective.This helps stop the frustration chain. In The Witness there is no music, no story, no context, barelly any tutorials. . Even when there is sound, the effects are minimal and create no mood. So what is left? Graphics, which are nice, puzzles and criptic clues for said puzzles. The simple fact i found in the first two hours of play is that if you take out humor, and other distractions such as Elohim or Glados all you have to think about is your own frustration with some puzzle. Because of that even when i solved the puzzle i didn't feel smart. I felt stupid for taking so long. Also even in the first two hours of play i encounterd two very simple puzzles made hard in an artificial manner: maze puzzles, and regular puzzles translated in the enviroment.  Again i din't feel smart at all. I just felt frustration. This game could have been amazing with some relaxing music to help with player frustration and just a bit more story. The way it is, i can't recomend it.*5 hours later*It a masterpiece. After the first two hours i was sure Jonathan Blow produced a 7 year dud. 												I have been waiting for this game well over 5 years and my expectations were actually quite high, but after playing it for a little under 11 hours it didn't disappoint at all. After a few hesitant moments at the beginning of the game, right after you leave the "tutorial" area and you begin explorning the island, the game absorbs you and never lets go.Each part of the island is brimming with puzzles that will leave you amazed at what you can actually achieve if you put your mind to it. One of those few experiences where you can walk out of it feeling fully satisfied of every second you spent playing on that island. At no moment you feel trapped or stuck on a puzzle for too long, as you are always free to leisurely move on to the next thing that awaits you on the island. The brilliant part is that taking those breaks actually helps you gain more perspective and aids you in solving those puzzles that proved too difficult at the time. With the right angle and/or spin, everything clicks into place in one of those so satisfying 'Aha!' moments that occur quite often throughout the game.If you are a puzzle fan of some sort, or you are someone who likes to give his/her brain an interesting challenge every once in a while, give this game a world. Just don't expect a lot of action, explosions or cinematic moments, as there aren't any on this game. Instead, you will get an inmersive experience in an island where you will rekindle that child-like sense of discovery that is very hard to come by in most movies and games.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												If you like solving logic puzzles, and I'm not talking like in an adventure game, I mean like in puzzle magazines and such, then you'll love this. I just wish they hadn't been so infuriatingly pretentious about the whole experience. The first soundbite you get is a quote from Albert Einstein, for Pete's sake! I mean, it's not one of the most worn out ones, but it just goes to show you where the creator (Jonathan Blow, I guess) thinks good philosophy comes from.This game is a lot like Talos Principle, which I would recommend you start with before going to this one. Mainly because the puzzles in Talos Principle are a lot more reliant on the medium (first person perspective) than The Witness. This game could really have been made in any format on any platform.That being said, the world built is very pretty and I personally like this kind of puzzle solving. The free roaming nature of the island sometimes mean you have to leave a particularly hard puzzle for a while until you've gathered enough information to solve it elsewhere. There is almost no hand-holding in the game, you have to figure out what to do by yourself. This is by design, however, so again, if you're the kind that is unable to leave a puzzle unsolved, you might not enjoy this. :)Some puzzle sequences are badly constructed. Two easy puzzles followed by one that is 50 times more complicated followed by one that is simple again. But I guess that's down to play-testing, something that Indie-games can't afford as much of, I guess (or is that wrong? sometimes I feel that AAA-companies seem less likely to playtest enough than Indie-game developers).Jonathan Blow may be smart, but I fear that maybe he has surrounded himself with one or two too-many yes-men. He probably should try playing "Magic Circle". Instead of the "Inspirational quotes" strewn about the island, maybe he should have written some kind of story for the game that we could take part of, or a bunch of little stories. These quotes just make me tired, listening to them drone on and on.

												I have gotten both achievements and seen both endings, and only have a few puzzles left before 100%. I have throughly enjoyed this game, but I must warn that it is not for everyone. This is a puzzle game first, not a puzzle adventure game. It is not like Myst. It may feel pointless or repeitive if you do not enjoy the puzzles. I do enjoy the puzzles.For me this game is worth full price. I never felt like what I was doing was mindless or repetitive. Every puzzle always felt like it taught me something new or challenged me to use what I knew in different ways. The game's environment is as beautiful as the clever design of these puzzles. Many puzzles seemed to know how I thought and actively cut off paths that I would naturally try to take, instead forcing me to get creative and try something else - this felt very refreshing. There are also several puzzles where your initial solution solves the puzzle but nothing happens, and if you solve the puzzle in a different shape it changes the environment to match how you solved the puzzle. For me this is the most rewarding experience.Not to mention the secrets in the game that blow your mind when you first discover them and then continue to blow your mind as you solve more of them. Many of them are a puzzle to even set up in the first place, and I felt challenged in a different way than the normal puzzles. It is very enjoyable.I only had to look up a walkthrough at two points during the game, and not to solve puzzles that I was stuck on, but instead to find out where to actually find more puzzles to solve.If you enjoy puzzle games like the Portal series and Antichamber, this game is for you. There is minimal story and the focus is expressely on puzzles, and you are free to play any music you want in the background or listen to a podcast etc, or you could just stick with the ambience of the game.If you aren't interested in actually playing the game yourself, you can watch my playthrough here for more in-depth commentary and spoilers:https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBCsoffCh90oOXDIoHd1PLOd6DkVRMBSV

												Initial Thoughts on The Witness: This game is amazing. I've only played for 6 hours so far and it has, quite literally, surpassed every expectation I had going in and, interestingly enough, scratched an itch for immersive puzzles that I didn't know I had. The game is beautiful, one of the most beautiful games I've played, but not in the sense of graphical prowsess but in the sense that it really feels as though someone laboured both time and love into sculpting this island (though, in having said that, graphically this game runs like a dream and looks the part (for specs and FPS, check bottom of preliminary review). This is one of those games where I, in good concious, can't spoil or talk about any of the puzzles or what occurs in the game for that would do a great disservice to the experience. All I can say is that if you like puzzles (and, yes, they are varried -- even if they all essentially are the same breed) and if you like immersive experiences, please play this game and please do not spoil it for yourself. This is an experience that needs to be your own. I can't wait to jump back in and see what else I learn.Thoughts on Performance: The game consistently runs well at 60fps (on the high setting) with a GTX970m, i7-4720HQ (2.6ghz) with 8gb RAM loaded from SSD at 1920x1080. Runs fluidly and smoothly and beautifully. A great PC game. Recommended for:Anyone who likes puzzlers. This is, at the very core, and exploratory puzzle game. I'm not sure if there is a legitimate narrative but that isn't what is gripping about this game. You create the narrative with your exploration and puzzle-solving. Do not buy this game if you wanted a game like MYST or a game that isn't fundamentally a puzzle game. The price tag is a bit steep for a puzzle game, yes, but it has been worth it for me so far. Wait for a sale if you are on the fence about the title but this has been one of my personal favourites for the past year.

												Think of The Witness as less of a traditional game you might find on steam, as an artistic gameplay showcase. It may seem simple on the surface of just click and drag puzzles to solve, but the way they are presented and taught are absolute genius. The game's art is phenomenal and an absolute necessity for the puzzle solving involved. Playing through this with intentionally no help really made me appreciate all the design decisions around the various puzzles and themes they have scattered throughout. The Witness is slow, repetitive, and you don't get much (if any) of a story out of it, but it's probably one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. Some might scoff at the price tag, but I think it's worth every penny.Story time. I had been banging my head against some puzzle with almost no way to solve it that was immediately apparent. Yet, when the envionrment interacted with me just right (shadow, or direct sunlight, or obscuring my line of sight) the solution was right in front of me the whole time. Cracking the puzzles and getting to that "ah ha!" step of learning is what The Witness is all about. It's not action-oriented, it's not hipster indie artsy-for-its-own-sake, but it's raw and simple genius.

												Some look at this game and see a collection of nearly identical puzzles.  I won't lie to you, you interact with puzzles in mainly one way in this game.  But the logic of the puzzles is so varied and challenging, and the environmental impact on the puzzles is very distinct and keeps a somewhat simple idea really fresh for hours on end.   Most games have a primary way of interacting with the game (in shooters, you shoot, etc.), and The Witness is no different.  But the way in which the game distorts these puzzles, uses them to challenge what you already understand, and incorporates a beautiful environment makes The Witness a memorable and very enjoyable experience.  The world is vast, with lots of places to explore and secrets/easter eggs to find when you want to take a break from the basic puzzle.  The Witness does follow the recent trend of not giving the player much (if any) story directly, instead relying upon the environment and some hidden pieces to build the story of the world.  This approach may not resonate with everyone, but I feel that it fits the story being told.  I'd highly reccomend this game to anyone who like puzzles or wants to think a bit when playing their next video game.  9.5/10

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												A beautiful, immersive game! To be fair there isn't much along the lines of a story, but there is something: some mystery, some history, plenty of discovery and wonder. Where the game shines are the puzzles. It's all about the puzzles, puzzles, puzzles. The reward is often the simple satisfaction of completing the puzzle, of learning something new that can be applied to yet another puzzle. For some this might not be enough, but I felt it was more than enough. This game gave me that "A ha!" sensation in a marvelous and all to rare fashion.Those who might say "well how interesting can it be, isn't it all simple line mazes?" as I did when I first watched the trailer need not fear. The game is so much more deep than that, one might as well look at a book and say "well how interesting can it be, isn't it all simple squiggles?". The depth of the game does not come in a varied interface, as true all the puzzles are interacted with as "simple line mazes", but in how many different ways the game presents to think about these seemingly simple interfaces. The progression of the games puzzles is truly masterful. There are no unlocks, really no keys or doors or "new zones". The only thing pacing you, or putting the game in any sort of linear flow is generally your ability to understand and solve the puzzles. Symbolic languages and mechanisms that build upon each other that you need to learn and combine to succeed.The game teaches you these languages and mechanisms without words, just through observation and repetition. It's truly genius, and I think could and should be a case study in how to write successful training systems.Highly recommended.

I unlocked the end game after 439+42 puzzles, and there are still more I'm discovering and working to complete. Those who are saying that it is the same puzzle over and over have not delved far enough to see what is amazing about the game. The puzzles are layered and layered, the starting ones are simple, the end ones are a nightmare, and I was learning and adjusting my thinking all the way to the end.If you are expecting an easy game or something to hold your hand you'd be out of luck here. If you are looking for a serious challenge that gives you a sense of accomplishment, you'll find this is the best game out there for that.

												If you don't enjoy puzzles please stay well clear of this game. Off you trot. Bye bye.You're still here? You LIKE puzzles?! Well get on in.The Witness is one man's vision perfectly realized. Having finished the game, I look back to the start of the experience realize just how much I have been taught about how the structure and flow of the puzzles in this game work despite never being offered a single line of instruction to as what the rules are.All puzzles in the Witness are solved by drawing an unbroken line from a circular node, through a maze and into a rounded end point. Interacting with the world in such a consistent manner avoids being repetitive by constantly switching up and adding to the design of the puzzles with masterful execution by the creator Jonathan Blow. In doing so, it also solves a big problem of many puzzle games - pixel hunting. You now know without the need of pressing a button or requiring a cluttered GUI overlay if what you are looking at can be interacted with.Puzzles aside, the game itself looks and sounds beautiful. The visuals are wildly varied between sections of the game, while at the same time still feeling like they belong together on the same island. While (almost) completely devoid of music, a solid ambient soundscape ties the experience together.At first I wondered why the island itself was even necessary. Could the game simply not be a collection of puzzles held accessible by a central menu? Having completed the game, I know understand the opposite to be true. The island is crucial.The Witness is a lovingly crafted puzzle game. I cannot wait to return to the island.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												This is pure genius!I did have utmost respect for Jonathan Blow before. Now that has grown to the level of hero worship, and I do not use the word lightly. What goes on throughout is a testament to both his brilliance and his ability to communicate, even through the most limited of channels. It does take intelligence to admire the game, admittedly. You only get to appreciate the layers of puzzles unraveling if you are able to unravel them. As you progress deeper into the game, you glimpse part of that genius, and in time begin to think alike. You grow and get to expect what comes next, and then you get amazed that the designer did foresee your growth, what path it would take and did prepare for that. You bubble with joy when you see the next surprise, that you deep inside knew was coming, but only realized it after the fact.You get to see the simplest of puzzle ideas, an application of graph theory, grow into an infinite playground in a fractal pattern, always promising to be more in the next step.It is amazing that this level of intricacy can be achieved, in any stretch of time. The development time, long as it may be considering 'industry norms', is nothing, considering this was the end result. It is exciting that yet more artifacts like this may come from Johnathan blow.There are all these complaints, from people who are offended when their intelligence is challenged. People don't play games to feel inadequate, many do when playing this. And many people tend to lash out so as to convince (primarily) themselves that the inadequecy isn't intrinsic. Those who can introspect, can grow, and that denomination is the target audience for this work.I have seen comparisons with Portal and Talos Principle. Games that fall far behind their promise (especially in the case of Portal). The puzzles were kept simple, as a design decision -to appeal to a wider audience, when they could be so much more. No punches are pulled here. The premise is extended far, far beyond what could initially be imagined.There are complaints that you have to use pen and paper. False: You also need a pencil and an eraser. The puzzles are so intricate that some of them would give you a headache if you tried to keep all aspects of it in your head, even if you were named von Neumann, and that is by design. If you think that is bad, this game is definitely not for you.I have seen comments that this is a disappointment after Braid. Ridiculous, I think: This game contains the seed that made Braid great: the ever-evolving puzzles, the extension of a simple mechanic to both technical and symbolic extremes, and the philosophical sense of wonder behind. Likewise it contains what made Myst great: The sense of exporation and loneliness in an alien environment, and the devious, ingenious, and original puzzles. Myst was never about the patchwork mythology pasted on it afterwards. This work captures the 'abstract' in them both, where most people merely grasp and look for the veneer, the packaging. I tried to avoid and spoilers throughout, but here I will give the whiff of one: The game _explicitly tells_ this fact within, showing that 'the dev team thinks of everything', even what most people will fail to grasp, and the few will.I have seen someone complaining when they learned to do something, and looked forward to 'apply elbow grease' to solve others like it was frustrated when 'the rules arbitrarily changed' in the next step. That is the point here, really. That was Blow's promise all along: There won't be any repetition, any 'application of elbow grease'. You won't ever get to turn off your brain and proceed through muscle memory -or its cognitive equivalent. Aside from some tutorial bits (where the whiners haven't even got past) the game always keeps you on your toes, always offers something fresh. This gripe, of course, contradicts with another that has been raised: That the game is repetitive. Well, only if you cannot see the puzzles for what they are and all you can comprehend is lines and boxes.There are those who whine about not getting rewarded. That's pitiful, for it shows that the people have become so dependent on the Skinner boxes that dominate the industry, not only need but also explicitly want the base gratification offered by them, for accomplishing trivial tasks. Here the gratification is in the puzzle itself: Admiring the beauty of one's own work in the solution, getting a nontrivial thing done, and getting to see the next puzzle. That is not to say there are no climaxes and revelations, they are just scarce enough to be really significant and deeply satisfying. And supposed dead ends are, more likely than not, part of some greater puzzle that you might get to see hours later.And in all that freshness, there is an amazing amount of content. It was immensely satisfying to get the endgame after 13 hours of play, and I believe I did very good time there. There wasn't the disappointment of it being over either: There is so much more to explore yet. And the game did make the promise with puzzles that -at the time- I could not fathom, teasing to come back after I did grow.Now all I hope for is for Blow to begin working on his next project immediately, and with utmost pace. I do believe he is a font that contains more to give than a lifetime of giving would suffice.---Slight spoiler, so beware:Seen the ending, then dove back in to complete the obvious extra objective. Done that, and when admiring the island in satisfaction, saw a curious little detail. Clicked around just for fun and got my mind blown. Chased the lead, and am feeling overwhelmed for the first time since the beginning. There are so many layers, and the sheer amount of detail makes one think that the developers _lived_ on the island all this time, to get it all 'just right'.

												The Witness is a puzzle game, yes, but it is also about learning, discovery, philosophy, religion, understanding yourself and the world. This is both a game, and art, and if you are a person who enjoys repeated "Ah Ha!" moments, this is the game for you. Rich in depth and beauty, any "ending" of the game merely unlocks new areas that remain to be discovered. Completing the "main area" took about half the time as every other thing I subsequently discovered, and I still am awed by the beauty and intricate details that I continue to find scattered purposefully around this island.You will not like this game if your idea of fun is blowing stuff up, shooting zombies or nazis, racing quickly, trash talking, achievement hoarding, a talky-story (although there is excellent spoken dialog), or instant rewards for solving the tiniest challenge. This is a thinking game, a game about enlightnment and what it means to understand, fully, pretty much anything. Some complained that $40 was too expensive. I feel it is too cheap, because the takeaways are probably equivalent to college courses on mathematics, logic, science, philosophy, and comparative religion, rolled into a highly entertaining experience.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												In many ways I don't feel qualified to write about this game. First of all I cheated. Out of the 300 puzzles I cleared to finish this game (out of about 700, I believe) I had to look up solutions for maybe 5-10% of that. Therein lies the shame, and the act of playing into the developer's hand of being an illogical being, driven by comfort rather than intellectual curiosity. Games have long conditioned us to look for help if we are stuck and to fully resort to the helping hand in such a predicament; this instead of our own ability or logic. Realizing this you are swiftly thrown into discomfort, playing The Witness. Because the game has a logic to it, but you can only rely on yourself to figure out the system in play. The mechanics are obscured by non-knowledge, but that's what makes this game so unique, and what constitutes its elegance and beauty as a game. I can't say that I have played a game that has required as much of me as The Witness. It requires trust and dedication, trusting that the game is working properly, that when you do not know something, that is what the game intends. And the only way a game can pull something like that off is with having absolutely impeccable game-design. There can't be any tricking of the player, in any sense. Blow mentions in an interview that he does not want to trick the player into feeling smart, which he never does with this game, but more so I think it's important to not trick the player into feeling dumb. Once a player start to doubt his or her own ability to solve something due to a lack of information, it's over. But even in this regard I think that The Witness succeeds in making the player feel like the answer of any puzzle lies within the game itself. My problems mainly arose when I knew that I didn't know, because I knew I disregarded certain places of the game where I felt like I couldn't grasp the logical rule-sets, or where I couldn't get over the leaps of logic even after I looked up solutions for certain puzzles. I conceded, there was no real trust in my own ability. That and my impatience lead to a certain mistrust of the game. But with this view back on myself, I see that the problem is not with the game-design, it is with me.Because I can't stress this enough, this game is elegant in a way I have never seen before. It is a self-sufficient game. It's cyclical, it is an exercise in the Nietzschean return. Repetition of fleeting activities, grasping at shadows of pleasure, the attempt to make something out of nothing, personal progression, are all parts of this game. Narratively, visually and according to the mechanics we are witnessing the eternal return of our activities as human beings, our purpose as lifeforms. The Witness adumbrates a great deal of humanity, an intimacy that becomes so much closer despite the distance required when viewing ourselves existentially. The Witness is this incredible holistic experience that encapsulates the art of game-design without profusion. It is clinical, precise and executed perfectly, which you will notice with enough trust in the game-design and with enough appreciation for game-creation. At the heart of this game – what is really the core of this experience, to me – is what goes on in your head, and what this game requires of you as a person; as a mind among minds, as a human being with intelligence. What I noticed fairly early on was my desperate need to vocalize the principles that each puzzle was run by. I had to vocalize this intuitively logical puzzle, just to wrap my head around what was required. This is not something I've ever really experienced before in games, and I was surprised to see it come out in a medium that is not often lauded for its intellectuality. Because this process of vocalizing or making conscious and intuitive form of intelligence puts it in the view of self-conscious scrutiny. This is a quality that can be very valuable for people in general, and in its own way The Witness has the possibility of teaching it. What I referred to earlier in terms of elegance, was in regards to the game-design, puzzle-design and the comportment of this game. This elegant restraint and non-compromise with the idiocy of the gamer's conditioned need for help, bleeds into its over all presentation. There is almost no music or extravagant sound-design, but runs the gamut of beautifully suiting each situation with an aural atmosphere that never feels empty nor mawkishly musical. It's this portrayal of life as “doing”, as functionality and concreteness. Every sound has its place, it springs out of the movement of the player and has a natural flow to it that in accordance with the visuals manage to structure a believable holistic world. Every facet goes with the theme of an encapsulation of being within something very fleeting, finding familiarity in a world that you're thrown into and out of, at least for the moment being. While this is the attempt, at least seemingly, it is hindered by self-hatred spawned out of inability. That is, however, limited to the dynamics of the individual, to what is deemed subjective. The Witness succeeds in creating a stimulating world in all senses of that word, to all senses. In terms of visuals, I struggle to think of a game I think is more beautiful than this. In terms of composition, level design, environment, colors and lighting, it's out of this world, but more worldly than most games. There is this marriage between naturalism and human influence, between nature and machine, between natural colors and vibrant neon, between vocalized LOGIC AND VISUAL CUES. When I get some time I am going to revisit this game with a fresh mind. I am not going to look up solutions and I am going to wholly dedicate myself to this experience. The Witness is incredible, and unless this game spawns a trend of games following in its footsteps, we will most likely not see anything quite like this in a very long time. I'm the type of person to be subjugated under things I consider to be more intelligent than me, and this game falls under that category. That means I am naturally inclined to praise it, solely due to the fact of it being “above me”. I have yet to master this game, even though I have beaten it, I don't feel like I have beaten it, and I that alone makes me impressed. I do not feel finished with the game, I couldn't happily move on from this game. Because I know there is more to it. I know there is more to learn and that curiosity will drive me back to this experience. And I think that is special. Especially special enough to warrant a recommendation.I believe this is a game where the more time you dedicate to it the better it gets and the more fulfilling it becomes. It simulates and portrays the essence of human – even personal – progression in so many ways and so perfectly, and it has so many moments of beauty and immense respect before the creator. If If I were to inhabit this world as my only existence I'd bow down in eternal love for its creator. I respect this creation and most of all I appreciated the experience. It was okay.

												I got The Witness after reading mixed reviews and I can now see why. I'm a huge fan of puzzles and open world exploration, and the ideas in this game are masterfully clever - but I don't think it's a good game.I never got tired of the core gameplay - the variety of puzzles available surprised me, actually, and it requires a lot of lateral thinking to get through them. However, I found myself on several occasions unable to progress because I hadn't noticed a very slight detail, even though nothing I was doing was wrong. You don't need to complete every puzzle to win, but it's still frustrating.My main complaint is with the ending. After a final round of puzzles that test everything you know up to that point, the game ends with two timed puzzles that are randomly created. Everything else in the game you can look up a solution if you just want to experience the next part of the game, so gating the ending to only those able to figure out a solution - and it's timed - feels petty to me. It didn't make the puzzles harder, it didn't challenge me differently, it just keeps the ending away from anyone who can't solve it. That, to me, is hugely arrogant game design.Then, after you watch the end cutscene, it puts you back at the beginning of the game. I now have the choice of playing from the beginning of the game with all progress cleared, or going back to one hour before I won. Not saving right before the end, in a game I assume partially made to comment on the player's obsession with completion, was just a little insulting.I enjoyed playing but I won't play again. It's maybe a $7-$10 game. Not worth it unless there's a really good sale.

												I was really excited for this game when I first heard about it since I love puzzle games like Myst, The Room series, etc. But 40 dollars is too much for this game, way too much. This game tricks you with all of its pretty colors and mysterious imagery, you think you are going to be interacting with cool things in the environment like you do in The Room and Myst, but no... It is ♥♥♥♥ing mazes. All ♥♥♥♥ing mazes. This whole game is mazes. Sure they do a few creative things with the mazes but after a while they get so ♥♥♥♥ing boring. It ends up being really hard maze puzzle after really hard maze puzzle after really hard maze puzzle... rinse and ♥♥♥♥ing repeat. It really kills the game, the bordom and repetition. It was so disappointing. When you find yourself looking up solutions to the puzzles, not because they are too hard, but because they are ♥♥♥♥ing boring and time consuming, then your puzzles have ♥♥♥♥ing failed. The best thing about this game is the (Spoiler) environmental puzzles. The first time you find one, it just blows your mind! That is where the game really starts to shine, but the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing about it is that once you get all the environmental puzzles it does absolutely nothing. It is so disappointing.This game borders on the pretentious. It is more a work of art than a game, and I think that is what kills it. There is no satisfying ending or closure of any kind. Sure there is a eureka moment when you realize what The Witness is about, but the problem is that that happens halfway through the game. The rest of the game after that point is just pointless. The game treats it's puzzles like they themselves are the reward for solving them. Which would be fine, if the ♥♥♥♥ing puzzles were interesting instead of just ♥♥♥♥ing mazes! I am an artist, and I went to art school, I understand what this game saying. The problem is is that it is just boring.This game ended up making me depressed, and not like a good kind of depressed like games like The Last of Us pull off. The Witness just makes you feel depressed, that this mysterious, colorful, and breathtaking world didn't live up to your expectations, that the second half of the game is pointless, the endings offer no closure whatsoever. And there is something else that I just can't quite put my finger on as to why this game made me feel bad. I just can't explain it. I guess it was just the disapointment. I was hyped for this game, and I thought it was going to be something it wasn't. In the end this game feels more like you are in a contemporary art gallery than a world with a story that wants to be told. It is very subjective in it's interpretations. It is a mystery without an answer and it shows you that what matters is not finding out the answers, what matters is searching for those answers. I personally love these kinds of concepts. They are not normally explored in media like video games, and now I understand why that is. Boredom. The Witness isn't about what happens at the end, it is about how you get there, but like I said prior, that would be fine if how you get there wasn't through hundreds of boring maze puzzles.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												Are you curious? Can you be patient? If both are yes, go buy this game. If not, you could skip this game, but I promise this game is worth the effort. Just know what you're getting yourself into.I can already tell that The Witness is easily one of the best games I've ever played in my lifetime. I'm roughly 5 hours in and I can't get enough. I'll fully flesh out this review at some point, but I thought it important to put my initial impressions up as soon as possible. Without meaning to offend, it seems clear that most of the negative reviews I've skimmed through, simply don't get it. StoryThe Witness is not about being told a 'story', at least not in a traditional sense. It is a contemplative, meandering conversation between designer and player. It's about uncovering a story yourself, through hours of patience and curiosity. There are so many mysteries to uncover: what is this island, who were its inhabitants, what the heck is with all of these puzzles? I've only barely scratched the surface, and I am more than intrigued. I'm excited for more, and without being spoon fed the answers. PuzzlesSaying that the maze puzzle mechanics are repetitive is like complaining that an FPS is repetitive because it makes you fire guns, or driving games are repetitive because you drive cars. The maze puzzles work BECAUSE they are the backbone of all of the puzzle solving. They give your brain a filter through which to receive all of the information that you collect by completing other puzzles or simply exploring the environment. It would be impossible for the puzzles to have the depth that they do if it weren't for the maze structure. The puzzles are beyond fantastic, a masterclass in puzzle design. They are always varied, always making you question assumptions, and always building upon the accumulated lessons that you've acquired. It's your brain that levels up, not your character. Truly brilliant stuff! Yes, they are crazy fun; yes, at times they are pretty frustrating; and yes, you probably should get out the old pen and paper once in awhile. They are more than worth it.This game challenges not only you as a player, but the entire medium of gaming itself. Come at it from a place of patience, curiosity, and a dash of discipline, and you will experience on of the most rewarding experiences gaming has to offer.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												If you want to suss out the meaning on your own, be warned that there are potential spoilers ahead.A lot of people are getting frustrated with the game, and it seems to be because they are overlooking what it is actually trying to convey.That's right, The Witness isn't just goading you to solve puzzles, it's goading you to think about what solving those puzzles means.While I haven't finished it yet, I can tell you that the puzzles are integral to understanding the core ideas behind The Witness. It is through the interplay of your actions, the scenery, and the audio that you can begin to understand the deep meaning that Blow was trying to convey. It shows a startling and absolutely genius understanding of how the human mind works, and how different types of thought give rise to different types of meaning--while also tying those different types of meaning together. It is not an action game by any means, because it is meant to be played at your leisure. People are used to plowing through games like a cheap buffet, but this is a feast and must be taken slowly. If you allow your mind to relax, the puzzles and meaning will fall into place--and that is an exciting and rewarding moment.Really, what Blow has done is create a game that helps you realize and understand just how much thought went into figuring out the world around us. At times I can even imagine what some of the great thinkers from the audio clips might have felt when a deep meaning or new understanding has finally clicked into place (probably a bit like it feels to finally solve a game puzzle that has eluded you).And it is exactly this that makes the game what it is. It is not just for your entertainment, it is meant to teach you something that the convenience of modern life has caused many to forget about humanity: that it took a lot of careful thought, daydreaming, and work--from many people throughout history--to get us to where we are. Sometimes it feels like you're playing inside a book (or someone's head), and I've never played a game that is so fully immersive.If you are looking for action, look elsewhere. If you want to play a game that rises to the level of great art: play The Witness.

content:
Posted: April 9
WARNING: If you are colorblind or slightly deaf and cannot either differentiate certain colors or differentiate sounds, STAY AWAY. There are MANY puzzles that REQUIRE that you differentiate colors and the difference in pitch of sound and if you are any sort of color blind or deaf, this game will not be your thing. I would LOVE if there were color blind options but unfortunately that would RUIN the game.Mazes? What fun!Bored of weird stories in puzzle games like Talos Principle and Portal? Want a Myst-esque experience but felt the "story" was non-essential? Do you just want difficult puzzles with various mechanics that will tax your brain? DO YOU LIKE DRAWING LINES?The Witness is an open-world puzzle game where you, the Player, enter an island that is littered with grid panels that are individual puzzles (most of the time). These puzzles begin at the disc shape and end at a curved point and the objective is to draw a line from the disc to the end. As simple as this sounds, the game makes this challenging by adding rules to the grids which you must follow carefully otherwise you will fail. Some of these rules are you must separate the black and white squares, you must draw the line over all the hexagons etc. Meanwhile there is also something strange about the island which you may or may not notice (you mostly will, it's in your face half the time).Story(?)There is a story... kind of. If you're expecting a linear narrative that goes from A to B then it's not here. In fact the only narrative you get is from narrations of quotes from various famous intellectuals that are strewn about the world in the fashion of audio logs. These really don't mean anything and most of what's happening will have to be pieced together. I'll say right now, there's no logic in what's happening so don't look for it. You're not there for a reason (not really) and what's told to you (or shown) doesn't matter to what you do. For all intents and purposes, you are on an island and there are puzzles so go solve them.Sound?There's barely any music in the entire game. The ambient sounds are very well recorded and play well into the game and are sometimes integrated into the puzzles. But my one criticism in this department (barebones as it is) is there's no volume adjustment AT ALL in the game. At times, especially in confined spaces the ambient sounds are way too loud and it gets close to becoming a horror game despite there being NOTHING to be afraid of.GraphicsThis game is EXCEEDINGLY beautiful. This is a pretty big open island with various themed areas that tie in to the type of puzzles in that area. Areas have been carefully crafted with many weird and interesting details that make you wonder what more is littered around. The textures are stylized and I feel the visual will most certainly hold up in a few years' time.GameplayAs I mentioned earlier, the gameplay is almost entirely the player tracing lines across grids placed at various locations, each with some rule that bends the nature of the puzzle. The puzzles are mostly fair with certain tutorial-esque sequential panels laid out at various locations that teach you a single mechanic which you will then use in other grids. Some grids will activate certain elements in the world such as gates or other grid panels which you will then use to move forward. I would say a good 95% of the puzzles are fair with few of them requiring you go out of the way to look for a clue around you as some of them use the environment extensively. There are definitely the occasional completely ridiculous and unfair puzzles but in the hundreds panels I've solved, there are maybe 10 that are just unfair. Towards the end there are some panels that made me motion-sick and some that gave me a headache which I'd rather just weren't in the game. One frustrated me so much physically that I didn't bother figuring it out and just looked it up because I felt weird and if I were an epileptic, I'd have a seizure. In most matters regarding the puzzles, the game is highly polished almost to a straight sheen. You cannot move where the game doesn't want you to and there is ONE method to solve each of the puzzles though there may be multiple actual solutions.My biggest gripe with the game is there is some sense of the game not respecting your time. There is no fast travel and the game requires you move across this island numerous times especially since you may come across a puzzle whose solution is not obvious because you haven't learned to solve it yet. There are also MANY moving platforms that move SO ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ SLOWLY. Sometimes they move slowly for a reason but it's still hard to justify especially when the movement of the platform is  tied to a puzzle in itself meaning you have to "re-solve" the puzzle to move it.ConclusionThis is a fantastic puzzle game that requires you use your wits to solve. One issue is that there's no real sense of satisfaction of solving many of these puzzles aside from the satisfaction of solving it itself. If you're the kind of guy that solves Sudoku puzzles for fun, you may LOVE this game. If you like puzzle games in general, I recommend you check it out. At $40, this is quite steep (the asking price is because the devs spent almost 6 years crafting it and feel that's fair) so I'd recommend it at 25-50% off. At $30, it's fair and at $20 it's worth every penny.
