content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												You'll find criticisms of this game, and importantly, they are not wrong, from a certain point of view. Just like some of the puzzles in The Witness, the perspective you take with the game changes the kind of experience you'll have if you try it, and just like the puzzles, it can be difficult to both understand and appreciate the game as it is. Many of the design decisions they took with this game are not in line -- no pun intended -- with what most of us would consider "modern game design." It's an onion that is surprisingly difficult to pull the layers back on, with each new layer providing new and even more difficult challenges. There is no music in the game. The island you explore is ostensibly "dead and lifeless." Your reward for puzzle solving can seemingly be nothing, or -- if you're rewarded with some kind of change in the world itself -- seemingly useless in nature, one puzzle unceremoniously unlocking another. The puzzles themselves appear to be flat, mostly motionless panels that could be exist just as well in a book rather than a game. There are no direct hints in the game; it will not hold your hand through its toughest challenges. To an unwilling participant, the experience appears undirected -- go anywhere, do whatever, but what's the point of it all? Is there a point? This is all one perspective, but shift your approach and you'll find the image changes dramatically. Suddenly, and without warning, there is a consistant, logical sense for why the game has minimalistic sound design. You'll understand the ploy of the island, insofar as necessary, and realize that it is full of life in the strangest ways. You'll find reward around every corner -- and you'll find the game nearly literally speaking to you as you traverse its windy paths, opening up new areas, and finding its most hidden secrets. The puzzles will cease to be flat, unengaging billboards on the wall, and literally pop out into the world, becoming multi-dimensional in ways you never expected. You'll find the game talking to you, helping you, and sometimes confusing you -- but either way, it speaks. The Witness is a game about learning how to learn. It doesn't pave the roads you walk with arrows, but it always provides a path to take to get where you want to be. Its puzzles are hard, but never unfair, and even when things are at their toughest the sense of accomplishment you'll find for learning and solving the challenges it provides is second to none. At its core, its a brilliant, meditative experience that provides a "Just one more puzzle" draw -- addictive and challenging, when you're willing to let yourself stop and think. In a lot of ways, it's like trying to communicate with someone who speaks a different language; appearing impossible, the more time you spend with it, the more you begin to understand its language, and the more it can speak to you as both a player, helping you with its mechanics, but moreover, challenging the way you think about problem solving. There are other layers to the game as well. Some philosophical, some visual, maybe even layers you won't care for. It's by no means a perfect game, but what it is is something unique and wonderful and challenging. I cannot recommend this game if you don't like other puzzle games -- but if games like The Talos Principle, Portal, and Myst are your bag, and you're willing to have a game that really pushes back on you, challenging to unwind its complexities, not only is the game worth its asking price, but you may begin to think its one of the greatest puzzle games ever.Or you may completely hate it. In some ways, it's kind of up to you.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												This game is a challenge, and it is a good challenge.  You need to explore, and be patient.  You need to think hard, and remember what you've learned in detail.  GameplayThe Witness doesn't explain anything, so you have to figure out everything on your own.  The Witness is filled with tutorials which explain game mechanics, but you have to discover them.  They don't look any different than any other puzzle.Between the 30 minute and the 2 hour mark, The Witness can be confusing and overwhelming, but it is supposed to be this way.  If you push on, and figure out what you can about the way the world works, you are in for a great time.ArtThe Witness has a beautiful 'brush stroke' art style.  The textures are simplistic, but The Witness compensates with overwhelming color, beautiful environments, and detailed props.  The foliage on plants is some of the prettiest I've ever seen.Music/SoundThere is no music, which at first was alarming.  However, the lack of music actually highlights the incredible sound this game delivers.  The sound design is striking, and powerful.  Doors make deep, resonant clanging noises as they open.  Machines whine and groan as they operate.  There is no shortage of footstep sounds, and each surface you walk on feels unique, and immersive.StoryWhen it comes to writing, and voice acting, The Witness is somewhat similar to The Talos Principle.  It is somewhat abstract and metaphorical.  It 'speaks at a distance'.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												"The Witness" is a visually astonishing game, not a single fault found with the graphics but as many people know its not just the graphics makes a good game right? As for the Audio, well, there really isn't much to talk about here as there isn't much to listen to in the game as far as I know, there are Audio Logs that can be found scattered around the land but even then they don't tell you much if anything about the backstory of this game. The one positive about the Audio is Very Meaty footsteps that are needed to solve some puzzles.Now for the Puzzles, The puzzles are original and can get very complex very fast with new mechanics around every corner and very little to no help solving them, however they are possible after a few failed attempts. What this game does with perspective is extremely clever and it can really make you think outside the box, yet, that said some of the "Forced Perspective" puzzles can be quite tricky getting into the right place to solve but not impossible.As for the mood of the game it is calming and stress free mostly however, it can make you feel like a complete idiot by not seeing the larger picture but then again it does feel very satifying once you have cracked a puzzle that has been fustrating you for quite a while.Now for what some people look for in these types of games, The Story. I can't comment on the story just yet as im only 5 hours in but from that 5 hours of solving puzzles and wandering the land I can say that there isn't much of a story, You wake up in a tunnel and thats pretty much all your told, The audio logs are just Quotes from famous people and tell very little of the story and I haven't found anything that tells me what happened to the "Others" or what will happen once I solve the "Final" puzzle.TL:DR  Amazing Graphics, Very fun and original puzles, Not much of a story, Not much audio but still pretty good. I recommend this game to anybody that wants a good puzzle to solve.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												The Witness sets out to be a modern day Myst. In that regards it had succeeded. Set on a mysterious island, you wander around completing puzzles. Rather impressively, these puzzles are all variants on the same mechanic, drawing lines on a grid. Don't let that simplicity fool you, these are hard puzzles that will leave you cursing the name of Johnathon Blow, the creator of The Witness.Like a teacher, Johnathon Blow will gently lead you through the mechanics so that you learn not just to solve the puzzles, but to understand them. A key difference in that brute forcing through them or randomly guessing will be punished. With many areas to explore, each with its own unique take on the line drawing mechanics, it always felt like that even if I was stuck somewhere, I could go somewhere else and bang my head against a different wall. All I can say is, change your perspective and be observant of the environment.One could even suggest that the island is like a metroidvania game, where the “item” is the knowledge you learn from each of the regions. This game is a chain of moments where you go “Aha!” and suddenly understand the key. While you might not be physically lifting that item above your head to the world like in Zelda, you are essentially doing that mentally. I am often reminded of Fez when playing this game. Although Fez has that one moment where suddenly you see the code of the matrix, this game has a lot more (although slightly lesser) moments. Then again, it can still surprise you and make you open your eyes to wonder just what were you missing this whole time and what else might be hiding in plain sight.Despite really enjoying this game, I did find a few pieces to dislike. While I can understand the choice in there being no music in this game, I disagree with it completely. But this is something that can be easily fixed by throwing some relaxing music on the music player. There are also certain classes of puzzles which some people might have a really hard time with. The “story” of The Witness is also very subtle and out of the way. Indeed the ending you get is rather disappointing. But it is a testament to the quality of the game that I didn't mind this all that much, helped very much by some of puzzles in the final area. Indeed the journey is much better than the destination. Even if all you get is the first ending after 25 hours, it is still a brilliant game that is well worth the asking price. But if you wish to delve deep into the depths of the mystery of The Witness, it can still be worth your while.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												I'm seeing reviews left and right of people dissapointed with this game purely because it isn't Myst/and or isn't story heavy. Nobody should go into it expecting Myst. It is it's own thing entirely, and that's a great thing. If you're on the fence about this game, don't set yourself up for any expectations. All you need to know is that if you like exploring interesting, well crafted worlds and puzzle solving, then you WILL enjoy this. This game was in development for 7 years and it definitely shows. The game developer really put a lot of love and effort into this. The world is beautiful, mysterious, and fun to explore. Each time you solve a set of puzzles, open up new areas, and interact with the world you feel more and more like you're uncovering some great mystery. The gameplay really nails the essence of what an "adventure" game should be all about. There's no linearity here. You are literally on an adventure while playing, constantly discovering things by yourself. The lack of in your face tutorials and story adds to this adventure feeling and will give you huge satisfaction with each bit of progress you make. The game has intuitivity down to a science.I consider myself a pretty picky gamer, and I will lose interest quickly if I feel a game isn't worth my time, but 10 hours into this thing I only find myself more and more excited that I might only be 1/4th of the way finishing it. Most game purchases I make will leave me feeling like it wasn't worth the money, but The Witness has me feeling for the first time in a while that I'm getting every penny's worth. If you're interested in this game, but feeling discouraged by the negative Steam reviews, don't take them seriously. This game is getting near perfect scores all over the place by major media reviews, and it definitely deserves the praise. The complaints that all you do is draw lines in this game are rediculous, don't take those seriously either. The puzzles vary dramatically in style and techniques required to solve them. The panel system you draw on is just a good vehicle to give a good sense of progression and variety of puzzles. Buy this thing. I feel like it's a Magnum Opus of video games, if there ever was one.

Posted: March 14, 2016
												This is a love-it-or-hate-it thing.Yes, the whole game is maze puzzles. Yes, there's barely any explicit narrative -- and the little bit that *is* there is buried very, very deep. I went 50 hours in The Witness before I felt I understood what the island was, or why I was there. And there's still some doubt there, frankly.And... none of that bothers me. I found the puzzles tremendously engaging. I felt like a genius when I solved them, and discovering the endless, clever twists on the mechanics was a constant delight. I was happy when my puzzle-solving prowess was, inevitably, rewarded with more puzzles to solve. That's what I wanted to do: it's just like an FPS game rewarding you with a bigger gun, and more things to shoot with it.So this all hinges on whether or not you personally enjoy the puzzle mechanics of The Witness. If you do, the game will absolutely fascinate you; if you don't, it'll seem an interminable slog. I don't think there's much middle ground there, and there's just no way to know until you try it.If $40 seems like too big a risk, there's no shame in waiting for a sale. For me, though, the game was worth every penny, and then some.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												I went into this game, not knowing anything except that it was some kind of puzzle game. After playing it in a couple of brief spurts throughout the week, I came to realize it's more than just puzzles.For me, The Witness is like a piece of artwork. It looks pretty on the first glance.... And then you start taking a closer look. You start seeing significance in each brush stroke. There's meaning in almost every single thing in the game. It seems like almost every single pebble or twist of the branches in a tree are designed *just right* in order to create this world. And indeed, it's difficult to miss this while playing the game.Because while the game may start out as just maze puzzles, it forces you to start looking at your surroundings differently once you free yourself from the walls of the starting area. You look at some of the puzzles in the town, with their bizarre shapes and seemingly impossible answers. Then you start to explore, and then you start to learn. What were simple mazes are now tracings, or they're representations of what you hear or what you see around you. It makes you stop and think each time you go around the next bend.And now it should be noted that there are no instructions on how to solve anything in The Witness. This is the part of puzzle games that Jonathan Blow seems to understand. The joy of solving a puzzle doesn't come just from reaching the end (while there certainly is a great amount of relief in that) the enjoyment comes from trying to figure out the solution.If you're in it for the puzzles, then you'll be in for a treat. For anyone else.. If you subscribe to the philospohy that games can be works of art, I would recommend it to you. I think the game is worth it simply to explore the whole island. I can't think of any other game that has been put together with SO MUCH attention to detail. I can't count how many times I stopped playing just to take in a view, be it a grand vista, a tight, winding path in a forest, or the curious shapes the shadows of a tree make upon a wall. Every little bit of this game has been honed to perfection.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												If this had come out last year, it would have hands down been the best game of 2015. What actually is it? Maze puzzles. Lots of them - 658 in all. Each puzzle is simple - draw a line from a circle to a semicircle end, while following the rules that govern the individual panels upon which the mazes appear. Some puzzles are designed to challenge you, while some exist only to teach you a certain concept that will be used to solve more difficult puzzles in the future.There are no tutorials in any part of this game. There isn't even guidance to any of the rules that puzzle components follow. If you come across a panel maze involving stars, an L shaped Tetris piece and three different coloured squares, there is nothing wrong with leaving the puzzle and returning later. For almost all puzzle components, there is a sequence of learning puzzles involving that component only, for you to teach yourself the rules that apply to puzzles including it. And this is where the true beauty of the game lies. Seeing a complex array of never seen before shapes and colours, and knowing that one day you will be able to solve it with relative ease has something of a charm to it, which is very rewarding once it is followed through.The game is nice and long - at about 25-30 hours to reach the ending and 40-50 to get 100%. There is no story, characters, objectives, events or even music; it's just you and an island of beautiful areas filled with satisfying puzzles. The environment itself is a work of art - more than just a walkway between puzzles. The visual appearance of the island feels ALIVE, seemingly inspired by painters such as Signac and Seurat, and is truly breath-taking. Although there is no story, certain parts of the game contain narration, taken from the writings of philosophers and scientists through history, providing interesting exposition to an otherwise cold atmosphere. These writings provoke thought into areas such as religion, scientific theory, human behaviour and belief.The entry price is a point of discussion, but personally I am unreservedly satisfied with my enjoyment of The Witness. It should appeal to those who enjoyed the Portal series and especially fans of The Talos Principle.The whole game feels thoroughly thought out throughout. Wow.

Then when you're in the final area flashing lights, colors, and spinning objects meet you and I wanted to throw up because it was so bad. By this point I was wondering, what were the developers thinking? You have a really good start of the game that was relaxing and quite challenging at times but then ruin it with this terrible ending. It's no longer about solving the puzzle in front of you, it's thinking about what redicioulus frustrating thing did the developer come up with to try and make this seem "challenging" but couldn't think of anything so was like, f the player, lets have them solve it while the puzzle spins at 1000 rotations a second.Beating the game was truly the best part(feel the sarcasm), you get into the elevator , start moving around then the game closes on its own, no errors, no warnings, no cutscenes, nothing. content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												I bought The Witness yesterday, and I've completed 249 of the game's puzzles in approximately 7.5 hours. There are still quite a few areas I haven't unlocked, and a few puzzles that I'm completely baffled by, but generally speaking, the game gives you enough freedom to keep discovering new areas and learning about different game mechanics in a way that allows you to progress continuously. There are several areas which I've finished completely, which taught some of the simpler mechanics that are built on in later puzzles.I want to give a little context on the way you learn about puzzle elements in this game, because I've seen some misconceptions in other reviews. The simplest puzzles are just moving a dot to connect a line from A to B, but quickly the game will start to introduce different symbols into the puzzles, each of which has a function and dictates something about the way you need to solve the puzzle.This is the important part: There is a tutorial area for each puzzle element that holds your hand through learning how it works.If you come across a puzzle that seems way too hard for you, then it probably is. The game is not encouraging you to try to guess the answer and get really frustrated. It's giving you a sign that you haven't learned the right tools to solve it yet, and you should be looking somewhere else. Every puzzle element, from black and white squares, to spiky dots, to a little tri-force looking thing that changes how different puzzle regions act, to things that look like Tetris blocks, every one of these elements is explained in a series of very basic puzzles (starting with just one or two squares as opposed to the usual 5x5 grid) that explains the mechanic. The rules, once you learn them, do not change. They are not arbitrary. They work the same way every time. There is a lot of challenge in finding a solution that fits all the conditions imposed by the different puzzle elements, but there is no guesswork.It's unfortunate to see a lot of reviewers quitting after an hour and a half of playtime because they got really frustrated with something they didn't understand and want a refund for the game. My own feeling is that the game does a really good job of slowly introducing you to new elements, as long as you just walk around and look for simpler puzzles before going straight to trying the most complicated-looking thing you can find. The game even turns off the puzzle panels if you try to brute-force an answer to a puzzle you can't solve yet--- take the hint.A few other things. The graphics are beautiful, with a very colorful, almost cel-shaded style. The different biomes of the island are each distinct and offer an impressive diversity of scenery, with each location having a different mood, and often with puzzle mechanics that relate loosely to the area (one region, overlooking a wide bay of calm water, teaches puzzles about reflection). The sound is minimal but effective; there are a few puzzles that actually require sound to complete, and because the rest of the soundtrack is relatively sparse, the auditory clues jumped out at me quickly. The one place where I think the game falters is in story, in that there really isn't one, even (at least as far as I've gotten) to be pieced together from the audio recordings and videos that can be found around the island. Myst or Riven this is not--- the game has a lot of atmosphere, but it doesn't have a narrative. As a fan of games with strong stories and generally of fiction with detailed world-building, it does seem like a little bit of a missed opportunity. But overall, I've really enjoyed my time with the game so far, and I'm looking forward to playing more.I'd rate this game an 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												The Witness sets out to be a modern day Myst. In that regards it had succeeded. Set on a mysterious island, you wander around completing puzzles. Rather impressively, these puzzles are all variants on the same mechanic, drawing lines on a grid. Don't let that simplicity fool you, these are hard puzzles that will leave you cursing the name of Johnathon Blow, the creator of The Witness.Like a teacher, Johnathon Blow will gently lead you through the mechanics so that you learn not just to solve the puzzles, but to understand them. A key difference in that brute forcing through them or randomly guessing will be punished. With many areas to explore, each with its own unique take on the line drawing mechanics, it always felt like that even if I was stuck somewhere, I could go somewhere else and bang my head against a different wall. All I can say is, change your perspective and be observant of the environment.One could even suggest that the island is like a metroidvania game, where the “item” is the knowledge you learn from each of the regions. This game is a chain of moments where you go “Aha!” and suddenly understand the key. While you might not be physically lifting that item above your head to the world like in Zelda, you are essentially doing that mentally. I am often reminded of Fez when playing this game. Although Fez has that one moment where suddenly you see the code of the matrix, this game has a lot more (although slightly lesser) moments. Then again, it can still surprise you and make you open your eyes to wonder just what were you missing this whole time and what else might be hiding in plain sight.Despite really enjoying this game, I did find a few pieces to dislike. While I can understand the choice in there being no music in this game, I disagree with it completely. But this is something that can be easily fixed by throwing some relaxing music on the music player. There are also certain classes of puzzles which some people might have a really hard time with. The “story” of The Witness is also very subtle and out of the way. Indeed the ending you get is rather disappointing. But it is a testament to the quality of the game that I didn't mind this all that much, helped very much by some of puzzles in the final area. Indeed the journey is much better than the destination. Even if all you get is the first ending after 25 hours, it is still a brilliant game that is well worth the asking price. But if you wish to delve deep into the depths of the mystery of The Witness, it can still be worth your while.

For those dedicated to the art of understanding. And while this game is far from being for everyone, I would say that all should try it. You might find that you are smarter than you think. And all the while you can enjoy a beautifuly crafted landscape full of all kinds of structures and hidden images. From puzzles placed before your very eyes to ones hidden withing the word itself, this game has enough to keep you going for quite some time.   So explore this world and look at everything from every angle, and in so doing, explore your ability to understand and bare witness to the power of your own mind.

												The Witness is a puzzle game and it is almost exclusively so. You will not find a story to speak of beyond the barest conceit. You will not find much music or action or RPG elements. There is nothing much to pull you through the game except the rather stunning scenery and your own sense of discovery. What you will find is a very compelling concept, stretched and explored in almost every conceivable way. It does not appear that way at first though. If you have do not have a little faith in the designer (by playing Braid for example), then you may be quick to dismiss it. It seems too simple. Too easy. But it builds upon itself over and over, folding inward and outward.By the end you will be swearing at Jonathan Blow. But again, that journey relies on you as a player. The game gives you everything you need, but never explicitly. You have to want to understand the underlying systems. Very often you will come across something unintelligible. Something you can’t solve yet because you don’t have the mental tools. You have to make note of it and come back later. I highly recommend taking notes. Pen and paper will be your best companions on this odd little island.This is a game that will change the way you look at the world and don’t mean that in some high-minded philosophical way, but in a very specific, rather funny way. That is something I don’t think I can say about any other game. For that alone, I think The Witness is worth playing.

												I give this game a thumbs up, but reluctantly so.  I think the idea behind the game is great and I would like to see more of the same.  90% of the puzzles were fantastic logic puzzles that challenges one sense of logic and critical thinking.  The artwork was also nice.The problem is that abpout 10% of the puzzles were just stupid.  They weren't logical, or critical thinking puzzles, they were stand in the right spot puzzles.  The reflection puzzles were fine as you could use logic to figure out where to stand, but some of the other puzzles were just random.  I was only able to solve those by pure permutation and looking up the answer online.  And those puzzles weren't even challenging.  If you know which arbitrary view is the right one, then you already have the answer, no thinking required.  You just have to view the puzzle from every angle and distance until something lines up.I want to get the answer by rational thought and logical pattern recognition, not by knowing where to arbitrarily stand.The other problem is that this game makes some of the puzzles hard by just assaulting your senses.  If you are color blind or, like me ,have bad hearing, then you are just screwed.  The puzzles would be simple if you could understand what you are seeing/hearing, but the game goes out of it's way to make it hard to view/hear the puzzles.  And I can only assume the puzzles at end game are designed to induce seizures and discriminate against the epeleptic.The sad part is that these crappy puzzles of arbitrary standing and sensory assaulting don't add anything to the game or make the challenge more rewarding.  It just makes it annoying, frustrating, painful, and forces one to look up the answer in order to finish.  I don't want to have to cheat to finish the game.To the author: You have a great game here.  It is fun, rewarding, enjoyable, and worth playing.  Just get your next game play tested by people and if somebody can't handle a puzzle due to hearing/sight/seizure problems then redesign it.  Even those who don't have bad hearing will thank you for it.

												You must ask yourself if this game is for you. It's not for everyone. There's no action, items, or enemies. The game is ponderous, challenging, and vague. Not everyone wants to spend over 25 hours solving puzzles, and thats ok. But if puzzle games are interesting to you, The Witness is certainly one of the best. To like this game, you must enjoy and be satisfied with learning new concepts and experiencing breakthrough moments in your understanding. If this sounds good, just buy the game, its fantastic. If its not enough, maybe skip it (or challenge yourself).This game is about puzzles, but it is also about learning, discovery and epistemology. In the end, it is about teaching you to solve its mazes while organically guiding you to moments of epiphany. While the game certainly takes itself seriously, I think that it deserves the attitude for how well it accomplishes its design goals. This game sticks to its morals and realizes them fully. The result is something beautifully unique that doesn't compromise if doing so would undermine its goals.It surprised me how versatile the maze puzzles are. The simple concept of drawing a line through a grid from the start to the finish is complicated by gaps in the grid and symbols whose meaning you must learn through sets of puzzles designed for that purpose. Eventually you are solving problems with multiple sets of symbols that must be satisfied simultaneously, speaking a new sort of visual language.Oh, and the visual are effing superb! Really, this game deserves to be played slowly, stop and look at all the pretty things (it may even be usefull...)

The game is trying to communicate with you, and it actually has a lot to say. Do not skip this game. If you get this game, and you're stuck at a puzzle, don't give up. Explore the world and come back to that puzzle later. Once you start to explore and begin to understand, you'll feel a strong attachment to the world, and you'll never want to leave.

												Alright, here's a spoiler free thing you need to know before buying the game: Good stuff:  - Amazing puzzle game. - You get exactly what you've heard in all official publications and reviews: it's a game about epiphany, and there will be epiphany. No control over keyboard layouts, game resolution... - No accessibility settings. Admittedly, Jon Blow recently tweeted that he's working on some accessibility features (mostly for motion sickness). - Spoilers for this game are worse than spoilers in general. The puzzles are designed to evoke specific feelings and experiences. Spoilers completely ruin those. - I really wish there was an "Extras" option in the menu. At minimum to replay all discovered audio logs.

Posted: February 23, 2016
												Th Witness is a difficult game to talk about, but I am comfortable saying that it has been my favorite game this year and quite possibly my favorite game of all time (certainly in my top ten).Aside from "I hate puzzle games" and "There is no plot", most players who down vote this game do so because they lack whatever quality it is that would give them the big "ah-ha" moment. The Witness is just that: one big ah-ha moment. If something doesn't click for you and/or you get frustrated easily, The Witness may not be for you.For me, The Witness never went beyond your typical "difficult". It started easy, got harder, and challenged me to think outside of the box, but I never had to stop. I never really left an area stumped to return to it later. The ah-ha moment typically came between 10-15 minutes each time I was stuck. This created a VERY positive feedback loop for me as a player.But anyway, here are some recommendations if you want to give The Witness a chance:1) Play with a friend. I played with a fellow developer. Perhaps the fact that we are game designers helped, but if one of us got lost, the other person usually caught the solution right away. It was very seldom that we were both confused.2) Accept that not every area is required in order to complete the game. I have a very busy schedule and have yet to 100% the game. Only seven of eleven main areas are required (any seven) to view the game's ending. Many have complained that Blow did not work to accommodate the visually or hearing impaired. Puzzles like this are NOT required and he claims to have even worked hard to try to include a puzzle that was only accessible to the color-blind (sadly it didn't make the cut due to the large gamma differences across displays).3) Sleep on it. The ah-ha moment is what you're after. The puzzles are almost never any more difficult than the previous puzzles (to an extent). A fresh mind and a change of perspective can help.4) If all else fails, take it to paper. A lot of friends made paper models to work out some of the more difficult puzzles. I believe that my friend and I only had a sheet or two of paper notes, but I am assuming that we weren't the norm.Aside from all of that, the game is beautifully designed. Many, many memorable moments and puzzles. Great visual and audio design for a game that can seem so constrained by the overall plot/setting. A remarkable experience, in my opinion.My first Steam review and my first 10/10 in quite some time.

												I have always been a fan of unique adventure/puzzle games like Portal 2 and Myst, and now I can add a new favorite to that list.  The Witness is quite literally a view into the mind of its creator Johnathan Blow. I give this game a solid 10/10 for its visuals, gameplay experience, originality, and game design.

												[UPDATED - 4/20/17]The Witness is Jonathan Blow's long-awaited Myst-like puzzle/adventure game, set on beautiful and mysterious island.Pros: - Fantastic art direction- Exceedingly (and nearly endlessly) brilliant variations on the puzzle theme- Lots of secrets and hidden things- Room to think about what the game means, similar to Braid- Challenging but fair; rewards perception and thinking- That great feeling when you finally figure out the puzzle that has been stumping you for forever only to be stumped again by another one...theres lots of this here.- Rewards careful perception, analytical thinking, creative problem solving and perseverence- Fun to play with friends- Ultimately is a vehicle for thoughts about greater things outside the game itself, and does a decent job of this for those who lookNeutral observations:- No music for the most part- This game is not for everyone. If you dont like puzzles very much you wont like this game.Cons:- A very small number of puzzles I found to be too much of a challenge or too subtly explained, including a few which are non-optional- There are certain philosophical elements scattered in the game which obliquely craft the story, like Braid. Unfortunately the game's story is very difficult to piece together in a way that is more than a guess unless you access all of the hidden areas, which means it will be accessible only to the more hardcore players, or to those who look up solutions online. I believe this is by design, but I also believe it would have been better if some of the key details were more accessible.- Solving so many puzzles can be tiring after a while-----------Overall: One of the best games of 2016. Absolutely essential if you are into puzzle games. Worthwhile even if you're not. Get this.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												The Witness is different. Extremely different. The closest thing to it is probably The Talos Principle, or in a small sense Antichamber, but that's a stretch. The only reason I bring this up is because those are the only two other games I've bothered to review, because I've loved them so much. And same goes for the Witness.First, as every other review tells you, its a puzzle game with a philosophical flair. However, a significant portion of the challenges is just figuring out what the puzzles are themselves. I could go into depth as to how it does things differently, but I feel many of the other reviews have covered that. Instead, I want to focus on some of my key experiences playing the game, which hopefully will give everyone a fuller understanding as to the experience that is the Witness.Throughout the whole game, I could not stop feeling a sense of wonder. The artstyle, the lay of the land, everything was designed so you had to just stop and look around going "whoa." What's better is that there are so many little details that you don't notice on the first pass. Sometimes the second or third. But once you really start developing an understanding for the world, you start paying more and more attention. And when you do finally notice that little detail, you realize why you missed it the first time. Originally you didn't know what to expect, what mattered and what didn't, and what details even existed. This is what allows the game to have such depth; it's amazing world and level design.There were puzzles I didn't even realize were puzzles! This sounds annoying and frustrating, but it is actually wonderful design. It forces you to explore, to discover other types of puzzles in other areas, and building an understanding for the problems presented to you. Then, as you explore, you start thinking "maybe I can apply this new technique to that puzzle I skipped way back when?" BAM. Epiphany. Best feeling in the whole damn world.Building off of this, the exploration of the game is nonlinear. You do not have to work through areas in a predetermined order. It gives you total freedom. So I recommend not getting too stuck on areas, and instead just continue exploring and learning. Eventually you will have the knowledge to attack that one puzzle.This game is not easy. Even when you fully understand the puzzles presented to you, the challenge doesn't end there. It pushes you to actually use this new understanding in more and more complicated ways. Patience is truly a virtue in this game, but trust me, the rewards are worth it. In fact, I started writing some of the more difficult puzzles down to try and use logic to solve it. However, like all formal logic, you need some assumptions. Many times I made faulty assumptions. Eventually I'd realize it couldn't be solved, and I'd learn which assumption was false, and overall I'd learn more about the system. It's an amazing feeling.However, I think the best experience in the game for me is when I had "beaten" it. Instead of finishing the game, I chose not to. I thought about all the stuff I might have missed, or didn't fully understand. The actual process of exploration, discovery, and problem solving is just that rewarding.So, do I recommend this game? HELL YES. Do I think it's for everyone? HELL NO. Again, it's probably most similar to The Talos Principle or possibly Myst (never played it :( ). Hopefully this convinced someone on buying this game; if you have the patience, it is an experience you will never forget.Tips if you actually get the game:- Take a screenshot of the map as soon as you find it. It's helpful- Do not be afraid to scour the same places you were before and have "completed"- As I said before, do not get bogged down by puzzles for too long, especially ones that you do not understand conceptually. Explore. You will most likely find something in your travels that will help you understand it.  - Take screenshots of puzzles or solutions if you feel it may be helpful later- Do not be afraid to write things down. Not at all necessary, but you might find it helpful as I did.- Open your mind. The overall experience is wonderful, but it easy to be bogged down by skepticism and impatience. Please, it is so much more enjoyable if you force yourself to be accepting and patient.

												This game is a masterpiece.  It takes the best elements of the puzzle/exploration genre (i.e. Myst, etc.) and completely eliminates the more frustrating elements of that genre.  For example, in Myst you could be stuck forever because you didn't realize some teeny-tiny pixel was a button that you needed to push.  The developers probably didn't even intend for that to be a hard puzzle, but you just didn't see it.  Well in The Witness every single puzzle is plainly displayed and very obvious.  Furthermore, the sequence of puzzles is obvious and the game does an incredible job of very fairly teaching you each rule you need to learn to solve each puzzle before later testing you on that knowledge.  This teaching was one of the more impressive elements of the game.  The end result is a type of puzzle where you could easily imagine the majority of them being in a straight puzzle game (no adventure or exploration, etc.) but that would be somewhat boring and The Witness has an excellent atmosphere of intrigue that makes you want to find out what is beyond the next gate.  The downside of this puzzle approach is that The Witness does not have the same immersive feeling as a game like Myst which had puzzles seamlessly integrated into the environment itself.  However, if that kind of immersive puzzle is something you love then The Witness actually has you covered there too!  I won't say anything that spoils the fun, but there is a whole set of puzzles that are not required to finish the game that do not show up on clearly marked panels...My recommendation to anyone who plays this game: DO NOT look up walkthroughs!  Seriously, you can figure it out.  If you're stuck on a puzzle just walk away and come back another day.  I can't count the number of times I was so close to giving up and looking up a walkthrough and when I came back the next day I was able to figure it out.  I'll admit I did use one hint and that was for one of the bird call puzzles.  But most of the fun of this game is in the moments of finally figuring out a hard puzzle by yourself.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												The Witness is one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It's a challenging puzzle game, yet like the best puzzle games, it makes the player feel like a genius for solving its puzzles, and it was never frustrating.It's a masterpiece for how a single mechanic can still teach and feel rewarding after 40 hours. This mechanic, essentially drawing colored lines on a grid, is made constantly fresh by introducing new rules to the player for solving these puzzles. In fact, the biggest challenge is often simply figuring out what the rules for each puzzle element are. Often, careful observation of the environment is required, as visual and audio clues may guide you to a solution. The game takes place on a beautiful, deserted island. It's rich in color, and yours to explore, almost in its entirety, from the moment you start. What works so well about the puzzle solving is that when you get stuck, and you often will, you can simply go to another area and try new puzzles there. You can skip many of the puzzles and still complete the game. Exploring one part of the island sometimes reveals a way to solve another puzzle that you couldn't figure out. Sometimes, the quiet, contemplative nature of the island puts you in the right frame of mind to solve another puzzle.Perspective, finally, is another major feature of the game, and when I finally saw it clicking in the puzzle and in the world itself, I was amazed.I was worried that the story would rub me the wrong way, as the developer's previous game had quite a few pretentious story elements (and one very clever twist). Here, though, all the written or spoken story elements are more or less optional. There are hidden audio and visual clips to be found or unlocked. I never felt like there was some hidden meaning that was being kept from me; rather, they were all interesting moments that I was free to interpret as I choose. I did feel that there were one or two major themes of the game, but it's left up to the player's own interpretation.The Witness smoothly teaches its mechanics to the player, and without needing words it does this teaching in a way that makes it feel like a discovery that the player made, not something explicitly authored by the developer. Out hundreds of puzzles solved, only a couple felt unfair to me.I strongly recommend The Witness for the meditative calm  of its aesthetics and the feeling of quiet success that comes from its excellent puzzles.

												[UPDATED - 4/20/17]The Witness is Jonathan Blow's long-awaited Myst-like puzzle/adventure game, set on beautiful and mysterious island.Pros: - Fantastic art direction- Exceedingly (and nearly endlessly) brilliant variations on the puzzle theme- Lots of secrets and hidden things- Room to think about what the game means, similar to Braid- Challenging but fair; rewards perception and thinking- That great feeling when you finally figure out the puzzle that has been stumping you for forever only to be stumped again by another one...theres lots of this here.- Rewards careful perception, analytical thinking, creative problem solving and perseverence- Fun to play with friends- Ultimately is a vehicle for thoughts about greater things outside the game itself, and does a decent job of this for those who lookNeutral observations:- No music for the most part- This game is not for everyone. If you dont like puzzles very much you wont like this game.Cons:- A very small number of puzzles I found to be too much of a challenge or too subtly explained, including a few which are non-optional- There are certain philosophical elements scattered in the game which obliquely craft the story, like Braid. Unfortunately the game's story is very difficult to piece together in a way that is more than a guess unless you access all of the hidden areas, which means it will be accessible only to the more hardcore players, or to those who look up solutions online. I believe this is by design, but I also believe it would have been better if some of the key details were more accessible.- Solving so many puzzles can be tiring after a while-----------Overall: One of the best games of 2016. Absolutely essential if you are into puzzle games. Worthwhile even if you're not. Get this.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												The Witness is different. Extremely different. The closest thing to it is probably The Talos Principle, or in a small sense Antichamber, but that's a stretch. The only reason I bring this up is because those are the only two other games I've bothered to review, because I've loved them so much. And same goes for the Witness.First, as every other review tells you, its a puzzle game with a philosophical flair. However, a significant portion of the challenges is just figuring out what the puzzles are themselves. I could go into depth as to how it does things differently, but I feel many of the other reviews have covered that. Instead, I want to focus on some of my key experiences playing the game, which hopefully will give everyone a fuller understanding as to the experience that is the Witness.Throughout the whole game, I could not stop feeling a sense of wonder. The artstyle, the lay of the land, everything was designed so you had to just stop and look around going "whoa." What's better is that there are so many little details that you don't notice on the first pass. Sometimes the second or third. But once you really start developing an understanding for the world, you start paying more and more attention. And when you do finally notice that little detail, you realize why you missed it the first time. Originally you didn't know what to expect, what mattered and what didn't, and what details even existed. This is what allows the game to have such depth; it's amazing world and level design.There were puzzles I didn't even realize were puzzles! This sounds annoying and frustrating, but it is actually wonderful design. It forces you to explore, to discover other types of puzzles in other areas, and building an understanding for the problems presented to you. Then, as you explore, you start thinking "maybe I can apply this new technique to that puzzle I skipped way back when?" BAM. Epiphany. Best feeling in the whole damn world.Building off of this, the exploration of the game is nonlinear. You do not have to work through areas in a predetermined order. It gives you total freedom. So I recommend not getting too stuck on areas, and instead just continue exploring and learning. Eventually you will have the knowledge to attack that one puzzle.This game is not easy. Even when you fully understand the puzzles presented to you, the challenge doesn't end there. It pushes you to actually use this new understanding in more and more complicated ways. Patience is truly a virtue in this game, but trust me, the rewards are worth it. In fact, I started writing some of the more difficult puzzles down to try and use logic to solve it. However, like all formal logic, you need some assumptions. Many times I made faulty assumptions. Eventually I'd realize it couldn't be solved, and I'd learn which assumption was false, and overall I'd learn more about the system. It's an amazing feeling.However, I think the best experience in the game for me is when I had "beaten" it. Instead of finishing the game, I chose not to. I thought about all the stuff I might have missed, or didn't fully understand. The actual process of exploration, discovery, and problem solving is just that rewarding.So, do I recommend this game? HELL YES. Do I think it's for everyone? HELL NO. Again, it's probably most similar to The Talos Principle or possibly Myst (never played it :( ). Hopefully this convinced someone on buying this game; if you have the patience, it is an experience you will never forget.Tips if you actually get the game:- Take a screenshot of the map as soon as you find it. It's helpful- Do not be afraid to scour the same places you were before and have "completed"- As I said before, do not get bogged down by puzzles for too long, especially ones that you do not understand conceptually. Explore. You will most likely find something in your travels that will help you understand it.  - Take screenshots of puzzles or solutions if you feel it may be helpful later- Do not be afraid to write things down. Not at all necessary, but you might find it helpful as I did.- Open your mind. The overall experience is wonderful, but it easy to be bogged down by skepticism and impatience. Please, it is so much more enjoyable if you force yourself to be accepting and patient.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												TL;DR: In short, the game does not have many puzzles that require much thought. In most cases instead the game just makes the actual act of solving the puzzle difficult.If you're looking for a puzzle game that requires actual thought, get this instead: https://itunes.apple.com/de/app/pushy/id322110989Here's the point where i personally gave up:Ran into the sound puzzles. Puzzles where one has to draw lines at heights indicated by bird song. Doable. Then the game overlays cellphones, wood instruments and more birds. These were entirely impossible for me. Game provides no way to make them easier whatsoever, and has no compassion for people who aren't great of hearing.--- Some more rambly details:The game is basically a very beautiful, mostly static 3d landscape you walk around in. It might actually be kind of relaxing if that was the point, but the point of the game is puzzles.The game's puzzles are largely not "solved". There are a few exceptions, but for most puzzles you don't look at and think about them much. In fact, for many of them the solution is just to look around and trace the line as indicated  by shadows, reflections, bird chirps or similar. (If you're colorblind an entire section of puzzles will be impossible, as the game lies even to non-colorblind people.)That is, for many puzzles the "puzzle" part is in finding where in the surroundings the solution is hidden so you can enter it. Usually they're either not hidden at all, or hidden such that you need to work out how the reflections ingame work (i.e. not at all like in the real world).Then there is a number of *actual* puzzle that require pausing and thinking. Those are actually more annoying than the previous ones, because the *actual* puzzle in them is figuring out what the rules of the puzzle are. You're literally just reverse-engineering a black box. This would be fine if there were a lot of different things to try, maybe have the ability to rearrange the pieces on the board and see how that changes the solution. Instead however you have a fixed set of inputs to which you can add your solution and get a yes or no for whether it is right. Sadly often the inputs don't explain all the details of the rules however, so when the complexity steps up, you're just left guessing and hoping and eventually brute-forcing it.Some rule-based puzzles i still don't know what the rules are, even after having looked up the solutions, and i'm a programmer by trade.There's also no story. All you get is a bunch of mp3s of scientists of various ages telling you how science is actually religion.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												The Witness is a beguiling game of deceptive simplicity. You'll see a lot of criticism aimed at it from people who have only scratched the surface of the game distiling the game down to "just tracing line puzzles". While it is true a large selection of the game are maze-like puzzles where you attempt to trace one unbroken line to the end without overlapping itself, the variations on this are vast and fascinating. Whie traversing this beautifully constructed digital island you unravel the various ruleset of these puzzles with non-verbal communication. This game has a lot more in common with the Cyan Worlds games (Myst, Riven, etc.) but instead of pushing an archaic, aging button to activate a portion of a puzzle like in Myst, The Witness unifies all contraptions into a unified puzzle language which serves to thematically tie all puzzles together.But the true beauty is in the story and narrative provided. You have to work hard in order to piece together the "story" of this place you find yourself in, but its a grand combination of philosophies from a myriad of schools of thought presented in a way that only video/computer games can provide. The story being told in The Witness isn't one of sci-fi mysticism, but instead the story presented wants you to meet it more than halfway. It wants to hear your own ideas and preceptions as much as it wants to present its own.This is also a hard game to talk about without giving away a lot of what makes it so special, and that discovery is a large part of its genius. So $39.99 is really a cheap ticket of entry for an experience that is priceless, but I also realize that the experience isn't for everyone but it was definitely an experience I enjoyed thoroughly.

												Honestly this game is fairly overrated.  The puzzles are all interesting enough but it has a pretty big problem with tutorializing.  Due to the open world nature, you can often stumble into puzzles that you have not been taught.  This can end in three ways: 1) you realize that you have not been taught this puzzle and leave. 2) You beat your head against it untill you give up, then eventually find the tutorial and come back. 3) you figure out the rule, then feel cheated when you evenutally find the intended tutorial.  In this way, while I like the game and recommend it fully to anyone who likes puzzlers, the Witness has a nasty habit of wasting your time.  Boats and platforms take forever to move.  This is a game that does not respect you or care about you.... but it's still good... great puzzles, interesting puzzle types, and a beautiful world.  My only advice: give up on puzzles early.

												Jonathan Blow showed his game dev prowess again by releasing 'The Witness' this year, proving one more time that he deserves the crown when it comes to puzzle games.The Witness is a complex first-person puzzle game where you roam around an island and discover its secrets. On the surface this is a game where you connect dots on monitors scattered around the island, but after a while of playing you realize that it is so much more than that.The controls are simple: You can walk around, interact with monitors and draw lines through mazes, that's it. You might think that just drawing lines through mazes is not enough for a 20-30hour game full of content, but believe me, it is.The attention to detail and love put into the environment (which is part of many puzzles!) is out of this world. The island is HUGE and with time you realize that every little detail could be a clue to a puzzle on the island.If you love putting your brain to work and enjoy being stuck for an hour at one single puzzle, then go ahead and buy this game. It combines simple puzzles with a gorgeous world full of discovery and makes you feel like a genius when solving a particularly hard puzzle.Personally, The Witness is my favorite game of 2016.

												Very beautiful graphics and soothing sound, excellent atmosphere and feeling.The difficulty of puzzles is next to impossible to evaluate because many are easy, some medium and few are hard. Some are even impossible or require unbelievable will to solve -- but for every person it is different. There may be a kind of probability but I was stuck on an extremely simple puzzle for a long time and then swept through many following puzzles without a hitch, and it was not a matter of comprehension. It is just a bit of luck on how you look at it and not necessarily a matter of comprehension, intelligence or other personal traits.You'll have to live with those "dumb feeling" moments if you want to enjoy the game.My advise is to play as far as you feel comfortable without spoilers but if you feel like you need it, don't think it is wrong to cheat and look solutions up on the 'net. Afterwards you'll feel guilty and like you've ruined the fun, so do this with caution. But sometimes I can tell you some very hard puzzles I was HAPPY to have them looked up, because I knew I could never do those. For example the ones where you have to pay attention to "something" (I don't want to spoil here) and then "translate" that "something" into the solution. Well, it happens that I simply can't perceive that "something" even if I know what it is, I have the solution and try hard. I simply don't "perceive" it that way so I'd never come up with that solution.Other times I solved puzzles without having a clue how, even hourse later and all, I still don't know how I did some. Maybe just luck?Then there are the citations from literature. They are interesting but they feel more like overshooting or wannabe genius. No denying that "The Witness" is a masterpiece that will be remembered for a very very long time. I value it a lot, it's one of the best games I've played in the last years. But, come on. Einstein and philosophers? It certainly is meant as a tribute to those luminaries, but this is still a game and a COMMERCIAL PRODUCT, not a piece of art.To be true art it must be something to put into a museum, teach in school or to release into the public domain for all humanity to enjoy for free. And neither of these is the case. This is still a commercial game, and as such the altruistic citations don't sound sincere enough to me.You want the real deal? Stop playing computer games and read an academic text about any topic (philosophy, art, social sciences or whatever) that you can download for free from any university. You'll get pretty soon the difference between this "intellectual posing" and the real thing.That said, I still recommend it over and over again. If you like puzzles, Myst or exploration games on solitary islands.. then this is the best you can get.Also, take some screenshots of beautiful sights and use them as desktop wallpapers! You'll be surprised how beautiful this game really looks.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												The Witness is a puzzle game with a minimal amount of story but an absolutely beautiful world to explore, with an excellent merging of the puzzles you solve and the environment you're in.It is unabashedly a puzzle game, and it has extremely well-crafted and insanely difficult puzzles, while still providing a natural learning progression without hand-holding and annoying tutorials. You start by solving easy puzzles, then harder, then harder still. The reward for solving puzzles is most often more puzzles, like the games Hexcells, Hook, or Snakebird. Occasionally you find audio logs that give philosophical perspective from famous thinkers like Einstein, Nicholas of Cusa or Heisenberg.But make no mistake about it - this is a puzzle game, and like the other games I listed, the reward for tackling a grueling puzzle is solving it. Some people will not like the lack of RPG Puzzle Experience Points™ or new and exciting guns with which to take down tougher puzzles, but it's not that kind of game.  The game is about taking in the surrounding and using it to solve puzzles.The puzzles themselves are brilliant. Even though they all take the same general form (You need to find a path through a maze) there is an ENORMOUS amount of variety. Furthermore they are brilliantly paced and the game does an excellent job of teaching you the rules non-verbally. You'll come up across two or three puzzles with a new symbol, think you understand it, but then the game will force you to deal with a puzzle that makes you tweak the way you thought it worked.  Regardless of what some detractors say, there is not a single puzzle in the game that 'breaks the rules'. It is perfectly consistent.Some real criticisms: The trailer promises a story about regaining your memory, but that is absolutely 100% not in the game. Some of the areas are incredibly unfriendly to people with disabilities like color-blindness or deafness. Some of the quick but tough puzzles turn off on wrong guesses (to stop people from bruteforcing them) and you need to resolve the previous puzzle (the solution remains on the panel, so it's not difficult) so that can be annoying.However these flaws are minor compared to the excellent puzzle crafting, the beauty of the island, and the mind-opening fusion of the two. This game is heartily recommended to people who like puzzle games.Small spoiler for people who "don't get it": If all you've done is walk from puzzle to puzzle, making guesses until you move on, and then finish the game without looking around, you're going to have a bad time. The environment MATTERS. Go to the mountain. Take a look down at the river. Open your eyes.

Posted: August 23, 2016
												I reviewed this really shortly after the game came out, but I feel differently about it now that it's had time to sink in, so I deleted it and am leaving this one instead.On the surface, this is a puzzle game. You explore an island while solving puzzles involving drawing lines on panels. Despite how repetitive it may sound, you can get a lot of enjoyment, surprise, and satisfaction out of this game just from that surface layer. There are some preachy sounding quotes you can find, and there isn't much of a story, but if you focus on the puzzles and you like puzzles, you'll like this game.However. The game goes deeper than that. If you really pay attention to everything you're doing, and pay attention to the environment, and really listen to what the quotes are saying in relation to the game's design rather than just dismissing them for sounding pretentious, it's like a whole other game. My first playthrough took about 14 hours to activate all the lasers and reach the "minimum completion" ending. Since then, I've probably put in three times as much time just going back and understanding the significance of random things in the game (the rest has been speedrunning mostly). You can solve all the puzzles multiple times and still notice new things in consecutive playthroughs. This game has layers, but they're subtle layers; the game gives back what you put into it. And I think that's what makes this game truly special.Anyway, back to surface level stuff: eventually you realize there is a story. Finding that is cool. And the "Complete a certain challenge" achievement is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Art and sound design are great, although there is no soundtrack, so the silence can make the game feel "empty" at times, depending on your take of it.tl;dr - Fantastic puzzle and art design. Game may feel empty and pointless at times, but look a little deeper and you'll find a reason for pretty much everything.

content:
Posted: February 10
												Quick summary: The Witness is a great first person puzzle game with little exploration and a lot less story.Pros:+ The game has tons of optional content so it can be finished by practically any adult but still offers a lot of challenge to those who are willing and able.+ The average quality of the puzzles is great.+ There is a surprising amount of variety in the puzzles regardless of the simple basic concept (drawing lines on a grid).+ The game doesn't use tips, manuals, guides or anything else in teaching the mechanics to the player. It uses the player's own deduction.Cons:- Some of the puzzles are more about eliminating impossible approaches than figuring out the possible ones.- Due to the game challenging the player in so many ways, some people will have limitations that can make some of the puzzles feel impossible, unfair or illogical.- At least I wasn't able to find a proper story or similar experience in the game.More in-depth thoughts:I strongly recommend The WItness to any puzzle fan. I also strongly recommend playing the game "in the right" way: stop to think about each puzzle you can find but if after trying to solve it, it feels impossible, move on and come back later. Solving puzzles in The Witness can be divided into three steps:1. Find the puzzle.2. Figure out the rules of the puzzle.3. Solve the puzzle.And each step can be a puzzle on its own. This means that you will be missing a lot of puzzles at first but realize it later. This means that you will find puzzles that use rules you haven't yet figured out, and it is not reasonable to try to figure them out there. This also means that you'll get those 'Heureka!' moments all the time when you realize something you had missed or misinterpreted, or something similar, earlier.Playing The Witness made me feel that Jonathan Blow wanted to challenge himself after the huge success with Braid and set to make an excellent puzzle game with a core mechanic so simple that a child could have made it with pen and paper centuries ago. It was a delight to see how amazingly varied the puzzles ended up being with such a simple core mechanic. This is one of the only games where few video reviews did practically nothing to provide me an understanding of the gameplay. All I can say is that the grid is not the puzzle, it is nothing more than an input mechanism. The input mechnism could be writing, shooting, jumping, etc. The quality, depth and the variety of the puzzles lies in the puzzles themselves, not in the input mechanism.

												Oh boy...this is a tough one to review.At the time of this review I only put 1 hour into The Witness.  I believe after scouring most of the island and doing alot of the puzzles, I can make an accurate first impression.  So you load in and find yourself in a tunnel.  You walk through it and find yourself in a beautiful fort area.  The graphics here were really well done.  Very colorful and differentiated.  After solving the first puzzle, you leave this closed area and can traverse the island freely.  After seeing a few more puzzles and completing them you begin to see a pattern.  All the puzzles use the same mechanic. You draw a line from one area to another area, and usually have to cover all the dots along the way.  I've seen this before in a tablet game called Lyne.  So the whole time, you are walking around admiring the scenery.  You notice there's no soundtrack, no monologue or narration.  No notes, books or posters...basically what I'm getting at here is, nothing to tell you about where you are or what this place is.  In a way, this can be helpful to the overall immersion of the island.  For me however, growing up with games like Myst and Riven, this was a deterent.  I never felt immersed in TW.  I just felt bored after that first hour.  I found that none of the puzzles made any sense in their placement.  You've got a shed area here, giving you 5 screens of the same puzzle that just gets harder.  Then over there, maybe 50 ft away, you've got a tree puzzle with the same line mechanic on different screens.  Then another 100 ft down a path, you've got a laser puzzle.  There is no lore.  It just feels like an island of puzzles condensed in a small area.I will give TW credit where credit is due.  Some of the puzzles are difficult and you feel a sense of accomplishment after completing them.  But with a price tag 0f 40 USD, I don't think this game is worth it.  Some polish needs to be done.  Like in the very beginning fort region, you can just walk through a sofa.  I feel like if they just added some music or more sound effects other than the wind, it would be a lot more immersive.  Maybe change up the puzzle design here and there.  Some of the puzzles require you to just look at the environment.  No spoilers, but the tree puzzle is a lot easier if you look at the placement of the trees.  In the end, I just didn't feel like I was a part of this world.  Almost felt like it was a tech demo that the developer of Braid made to see if he could do a puzzle game.  I wouldn't even call this an adventure game.  Once the price comes down to 20 USD I'd say pick it up.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												The Witness is one of those games that’s hard to describe due to spoilers. In the most basic sense, it’s a puzzle game in which you interact with panels that are simple mazes, but really, the game gets so much more complex. Every area of the island in The Witness has a set of rules that govern the puzzles found there. You will learn what those rules are through what you could say are tutorial puzzles. Some later puzzles in areas will draw from the rules of other areas, so you start mixing two, three, four, etc… rule sets together and this results in some seriously complex puzzles. Again, I cannot say too much as I don’t want to spoil anything, but many of these puzzles got so complex that I found myself grabbing a pen and some paper and actually writing notes and drawing diagrams. I took more notes while playing The Witness than I did while working on my Master’s degree. One puzzle, not due to the difficulty of it, but due to how it’s presented to the player, gave me a headache. This isn’t entirely bad and I can’t really explain why, again due to spoilers, but I just want to try and let you know as much as I can without spoiling, that the game does really spice things up and is far more than just solving some simple mazes.I should also add that I played The Witness in a sort of co-op mode. I played it along with a buddy of mine and we went from puzzle to puzzle, area to area in our own respective game while we communicated via TeamSpeak. Where one of us struggled, the other helped. This made it so that we never had to resort to using any online walkthroughs. We never really lost that sense of accomplishment in solving the puzzles by having to cheat online. The Witness is a game that will make you feel like a genius just as many times as it makes you feel like an idiot. It will haunt your dreams and warp your brain once you’ve finished it. You will start to see things in the real world and you will want to interact with them as you had in The Witness. The is most likely my favorite game of 2016, I’m sure it will have a place in my top 10 games of the last decade, and it is even in the running for one of my favorite gaming experiences of all time. 5/5

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												The Witness is a dreadfully difficult game to review. In part because, as a puzzle game, most of the joy comes from discovery and the understanding of what the game is trying to teach you, and so it is dangerous to say too much... But also because I could write entire essays about why I'm so thrilled about it. I'll try to keep it concise.This is the best puzzle game I've ever played. It is no doubt a worthy and logical successor to Braid, even if the games have nothing in common on a mechanical level. It's downright amazing how elegant the puzzle mechanics are, just how much mileage Mr. Blow and friends got out of them, and how simultaneously intuitive and challenging it can be to grasp them.At this point, if you know that you really do like puzzles, you should probably just buy this game.The biggest praise, coming from me, is that I've "beaten" the game several days prior to writing this, but I still don't feel done with it. Whereas something like Antichamber kept my attention for about two hours before losing me, after which I didn't feel engaged to keep trying to find my way through it, and many other puzzle games keep me focused for half the length of the game before impatience and headaches get the better of me and I beeline it to the ending, never looking back, I keep returning to the eerily perfect island of The Witness. Just a few minutes a day, just to wander around and hopefully discover something new. I wish I could explain why I'm not sick of it yet, but I can't. I just know there's more to do, and though I feel frustrated one day for not making progress, I'll come back another time and feel as if it was obvious all along.At this point, if it's the pricetag the worries you, or the concept of a silent world devoid of anything but puzzles and nothing to keep you going, then don't worry. There is plenty of substance to The Witness. Perhaps there won't be an exciting, driving narrative to push you onward, or interesting characters to meet and have demand things of you, but you will find reasons to engage yourself in the world, and plenty of things to discover. If you're anything like me, you won't want to leave until you've unwound every single loose thread you can find. And even the ones you can't. Because it's only a matter of time.Bottom line, I don't think I've ever played a game that has managed to make the simple pleasures of discovery and understanding feel so thoroughly rewarding. I don't do ratings, but if I did, this game would get five stars out of five. Puzzles will never be the same.
