Posted: March 22, 2016
												2:30 am, sitting in my chair and asking myself what I just experienced. Or should I say... WITNESSED?The Witness is a gorgeous puzzle game mainly created by Johnathan Blow. And that's basically it. It's puzzles. You won't have a portal 2 narrative that takes you through the game, no narrative at all to be precise. On the surface it's all about the puzzles. They start out simple with starting at a Dot, drawing a line to a rounded end. After you did that for your first solved puzzle you see a door with stuff in the puzzle you don't understand. It's not just lines anymore, there are things inbetween the squares! Not knowing what you need to do you will fail for a few minutes and go on or go on immediately. You will find yourself infront of a few new panels. Oh hey! They have the same elements on them as the ones on the door you couldn't open just a few steps before. These are much easier though and you get the hang of the way these obstacles work. You now know how to deal with this obstacle and which rule they integrate to the puzzle scheme. The door is yours to open now. And this is how the witness basically does every bit of puzzling. But sometimes the solution for puzzles are not only the mechanics within them but looking at them with different coloured light, using sound or using the environment for clues are also things you need to do to solve for probably 1/3rd of the puzzles. Yet most of the time you see something new and don't quite understand what to do but a few steps away (or in a different region of the open world island) you find panels explaining you the rules this new obstacle establishes and you can then go back to what you found to solve the puzzle you couldn't solve before. The open world of the witness really serves it well. Stuck at a certain point in an area? No problem, look into another one or explore the world to find new ones and come back later to get a new perspective without any preoccupation on the solution. Introducing new mechanics is something the witness does exceptionally well without saying or writing a single word about them.You might ask yourself what motivates you during this journey, all on your own and without any narrative, which is a great question.The moment you solve a puzzle, the right idea pops in mind and you realize it was your own head standing in your way the whole time but you just overcame this hurdle, is amazing. And even though I found this to be even more fulfilling in the witness, I see that many people will probably have a problem with that form of motivation but normally you are probably♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off that a puzzle takes you out of the narrative of the game just for you to solve this puzzle which might even take you a good while - In that case the puzzles stand in the way of the narrative yet in the witness the puzzles motivate for more puzzles so you have nothing that they stand in the way of. The only thing in this game that stands in somethings way is your own head standing inbetween you and the solution.The witness isnot about anything really and yet making you ask many questions, not about the game, but yourself. There are loads of audio pieces (and actually videos as well) in this game that I would say, either make you think about them or make you not do anything at all. What I mean by that is that there is no real middle ground between the two. Most of these extras are talking about the way humans think, how they express what they know, what they even know, if they want to know more and why as well as just overall interesting stuff (I found so at least) about scientists and also spiritual topics. There are people and sites (destructoid for example) talking critical about the game, the values it seems to praise and the effect it has on the industry and the people thinking highly of it. And some of the criticism is surely deserved......but I personally found myself enjoying the little audio pieces and the clips that I watched in combination with the way the game introduced mechanics, the exploration, it's aesthetics + sound design and of course the puzzles themselves.So I would surely recommend The Witness, even for 40€ you get at around 20 hours of amazing puzzling and exploration. I'm looking forward to coming back to it and solve more puzzles I've missed in my 20 hours because the game surely changes your perception of where the puzzles are and they might not even need panels for them to be puzzles...

												So, I guess words fail me on this one. This game isn't fun... it's necessary. Although technically the puzzles progressively become harder, that's not the point. They progressively become more profound, and I'm surprised at how inspiring and thought provoking this puzzle game is. Excellently selected quotes from famous thinkers are sprinkled sparingly throughout the game to draw attention to the fact that there is art to be discovered in the puzzles - brilliance to be uncovered within yourself.Unlike games like "the graveyard," which try way too hard to appear like art within the form of a game, this game truly is art. The rest of the game is experienced through your own personal pursuit.If you desire introspection, if you want a slow and satisfying stroll through your mind, if every other game is starting to blur into one mess of combat and acquisition... the Witness is for you.

												The Witness is, at it's core, a puzzle magazine.The most beautiful, creative, detailed, immersive, intriguing (and, let's be honest, expensive) puzzle magazine I have ever seen. But it's a puzzle magazine.There is no gun. There is no inventory. 100% of your interactions are done by solving increasingly complex maze puzzles of some sort. This could very quickly grow tiresome if not for the absolutely brilliant design behind it all, as the game continuously asks you to understand what makes a solution a solution, then proceeds to twist that to create something new, again and again and again and again. The puzzles and locations are crafted with an unparalleled amount of detail. Everything has a purpose, and all of the greatest moments in The Witness come around when you realize just that. The game is pretty much guaranteed to put a huge smile in your face at one point or another.But... it's a puzzle magazine.If you are looking for something with a riveting (or, you know, existing) storyline or fast-paced action, this is not it. There'll be better ways to spend $40.If, instead, you are the kind of person who enjoys sitting down and solving puzzles, if you just love the feeling when something *clicks* in your head and suddenly things make sense, then The Witness is without a doubt the game for you.

												I went into this game, not knowing anything except that it was some kind of puzzle game. After playing it in a couple of brief spurts throughout the week, I came to realize it's more than just puzzles.For me, The Witness is like a piece of artwork. It looks pretty on the first glance.... And then you start taking a closer look. You start seeing significance in each brush stroke. There's meaning in almost every single thing in the game. It seems like almost every single pebble or twist of the branches in a tree are designed *just right* in order to create this world. And indeed, it's difficult to miss this while playing the game.Because while the game may start out as just maze puzzles, it forces you to start looking at your surroundings differently once you free yourself from the walls of the starting area. You look at some of the puzzles in the town, with their bizarre shapes and seemingly impossible answers. Then you start to explore, and then you start to learn. What were simple mazes are now tracings, or they're representations of what you hear or what you see around you. It makes you stop and think each time you go around the next bend.And now it should be noted that there are no instructions on how to solve anything in The Witness. This is the part of puzzle games that Jonathan Blow seems to understand. The joy of solving a puzzle doesn't come just from reaching the end (while there certainly is a great amount of relief in that) the enjoyment comes from trying to figure out the solution.If you're in it for the puzzles, then you'll be in for a treat. For anyone else.. If you subscribe to the philospohy that games can be works of art, I would recommend it to you. I think the game is worth it simply to explore the whole island. I can't think of any other game that has been put together with SO MUCH attention to detail. I can't count how many times I stopped playing just to take in a view, be it a grand vista, a tight, winding path in a forest, or the curious shapes the shadows of a tree make upon a wall. Every little bit of this game has been honed to perfection.

												This is a love-it-or-hate-it thing.Yes, the whole game is maze puzzles. Yes, there's barely any explicit narrative -- and the little bit that *is* there is buried very, very deep. I went 50 hours in The Witness before I felt I understood what the island was, or why I was there. And there's still some doubt there, frankly.And... none of that bothers me. I found the puzzles tremendously engaging. I felt like a genius when I solved them, and discovering the endless, clever twists on the mechanics was a constant delight. I was happy when my puzzle-solving prowess was, inevitably, rewarded with more puzzles to solve. That's what I wanted to do: it's just like an FPS game rewarding you with a bigger gun, and more things to shoot with it.So this all hinges on whether or not you personally enjoy the puzzle mechanics of The Witness. If you do, the game will absolutely fascinate you; if you don't, it'll seem an interminable slog. I don't think there's much middle ground there, and there's just no way to know until you try it.If $40 seems like too big a risk, there's no shame in waiting for a sale. For me, though, the game was worth every penny, and then some.

One of my favorite candidates for my Game of the Year 2016.

												You are in front of a mathematics test paper, taking an examination. A seemingly impossible fill-in-the-blank question has bugged you for a long time, you realize that with the given conditions, even if you exhausted all methods you have learned so far, it is still far from solvable. The clock is ticking, you fall in despair.Unexpectedly, a wind blows the paper onto the floor. While picking it up, you notice a semicircular coffee cup stain on the back of the paper, which makes up a perfect circle with the organic pattern of the marble tile on the floor. Circle was reminiscent of the sun, you stare into the sun outside the window, have your faith replenished, partly. Through a mere reflection on the glass facade of the opposite building, your split vision lands on the apple tree on the playground. It is an apple tree with birds on branches: a pigeon, a sparrow and a crow. That is, three birds in total, you ponder. Three, was reminiscent of triangle; Triangle symbolizes the Illuminati; Illuminati was founded in 1776 at Bavaria, Germany. Wait a second, the country code for Germany is …... 49!A sense of epiphany overwhelms your mind, you know you have made it. You write the answer 49 onto the paper, with a contented smile on your face.--- The Witness in a Nutshell[All Achievements Acquired on 4 Feb, 2016][Final Verdict: 78/100]

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												This is an interesting specimen. It's very similar to Myst, in that it's an island filled with puzzles. However, while Myst's puzzles are all combination locks with a note hidden somewhere, The Witness' puzzles all require some serious grey matter.The Witness' gameplay is incredibly simple. A first-person game where you explore an island and solve puzzles. These puzzles all take the form of maze panels. Each maze has a set of different mechanics. These mechanics, depending on where you start, are very simplistic, at first so you can get your bearings and understand how these mechanics work. The mechanics become more and more complicated and even mix into each other.The puzzles are definitely the best part of the game. Not only do they become more complicated, but the way you find the solutions are absolutely mind-boggling. The island is crawling with clues. Not in the form of notes, but in the form of the island's decor. The plants, the rock formations, the architectures...almost everything on the island is a clue. Look closely! These puzzles are incredibly well-designed and implemented.The game is also completely open. Each area of the island is yours to explore. This design choice also benefits the player if they are stuck on a puzzle, allowing them to walk away, clear their heads, and/or look to new puzzles to solve if you want. The game's setting is absolutely beautiful. Each part of the island is completely distinctive and wildly imaginative. A looming fortress, a forest set in eternal autumn, a beautiful orchard, a bamboo forest that could serve as a panda preserve, Journey-esque desert, and many more that I wish to not spoil.I have yet to 100% complete this game, but I'm fully absorbed in it's incredibly complex design.However, this game lacks a story (as far as I know and if it does, please don't spoil it for me). The game has several audio logs scattered about, but they're all real-world quotes that have no context.This game leaves me feeling both befuddled, confused, frustrated, and fulfilled when I find the solution (Though, I often need a pad of graph paper on-hand. In fact, I have a pad specifically for this game. The puzzles are extremely well designed, they're simple to complete, yet complex in execution, and absolutely beautiful to look at. If you're a fan of deep, intricate games, I highly recommend it

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Edit: A more in depth review, now that I played a bit.The Witness is a puzzle game that I personally only recommend for the most hardcore puzzle fan.You wake up on an island that seems to be completely empty. You have to explore it and figure out why you are on there, and what happened.The story is pretty light. Aside from some voice messages and videos of psychological and philosophical nature, there isn't really much story to speak of until, maybe, the end (I am not there yet).You progress through the island by solving the same type of puzzle over and over. Now, I am actually impressed by the amount of variations this game has for just the same type ofpuzzle. It starts off easy - draw a line from a starting point to an end point. As the game progresses, new symbols will be introduced that make solving these puzzles way harder, and sometimes even the environment will take part in the solution. For having only one type of puzzle, the game varies it a lot, keeping you busy and on your toes.The puzzles themselves are generally on the harder side, but if you love puzzles, you will want to solve them all without looking into a walkthrough. Trust me, the experience is better that way.Now, it is of course not all gold and sunshine. Here are my personal pros and cons for the game:Pro:+GraphicsThe graphics are nice and sufficient. The island has lush colours, the graphic style is detailed enough without being overbearing, and everything is generally nice to look at and resourceful enough to work on any type of graphics card, really.+Puzzles/CreativityWhile the game only has one type of basic puzzle, it varies so much over the course of its 500+ puzzles that it has more variation in it than 10 types of puzzles could ever hope to achieve. Symbols, dots, tetris pieces and much more will make every area you explore a little different and keep you on your toes.+SoundsThe sounds are well done. The footsteps are the primary sound you will hear, and they are just as satisfying to listen to as the wirring of machinery after a solved puzzle, or the buzzing of an activated computer panel.+SecretsThe island has a lot of secret puzzles and secret locations. Exploring it is in general very fun and rewarding.+Voice MessagesI like the voice messages in the game. While they are all only quotes of famous philosophers, scientists and the like, the people reading them really bring in some atmosphere. They do a great job, especially since everything else is so quiet.Eh:-+No HintsThere are no real hints or a way to progress should you ever not understand a puzzle. Now, the entire game is logical, and everything can be solved with logic, but should you ever not get something, then you can either explore somewhere else, or, if you don't understand a symbol, look at a walkthrough. It can be frustrating, but that is not necessarily a con - it makes you have to think about things.-+No MusicThere is no music in the game. Aside from the sound, everything is quiet. Some say it helps build up atmosphere, some find it annoying. It is up to you.-+ClaustrophobiaThe game feels downright claustrophobic at times, which is weird. The island holds a lot of structures like castles, deserts, houses, and so on, but sometimes it feels so cramped full of things that it seems unnecessary. That could have been avoided by just making the island a bit larger.Cons:-No MapThis is probably my personal worst point. There is a fast travel system by using a boat you unlock at some point, and it shows a map - but there is no map you can call on at any point. The island itself isn't huge, but there are so many things to discover that a map would be really useful at times - the game is kept minimalistic for a reason, yes, but that doesn't mean it isn't annoying.-No story (to speak of)Aside from, what I heard, the end, the entire game has no story, really. Yes, apparently something happened on this island, but until the end, you won't know what - that can make solving puzzles feel meaningless.-No rewardAside from progressing over the island (sometimes), a lot of the puzzles don't have more rewards, except more puzzles. The reward is, I suppose, getting to solve them. Which is why I recommend the game only for diehard puzzle fans.Overall, I think it is a game worth playing, but only if you love puzzles, can deal with a(n apparent) nonexistent story and no music, and like the atmosphere of exploring an abandoned island.My personal rating: 7/10

												Okay, this game isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea; it's hard as hell and some people might just brush the puzzles off as being dumb minigames that belong on an iPad.  I can see where those people are coming from but there's so much more going on here.First off, let's state the obvious: The visuals are gorgeous. You can accidentally end up in areas where you shouldn't be and won't have a single hope of knowing how to solve the puzzles there.  Even though the puzzle mechanic of drawing lines on a grid remains the same, the game slowly introduces new different ways that the puzzles work, but each time a new thing is added you essentially have to figure out how it works yourself with no help!  Sometimes it's obvious and other times you'll scratch your head and feel like you're about to tear out your hair before suddenly having an epiphany and feeling like an absolute genius.  I like that a lot and it adds an incredibly surprising level of depth to what some might assume would just be the same thing over and over again.If you're looking for something fast paced with lots of action, this really isn't for you.  This game requires insane amounts of patience and persistence, getting stuck is painful but once you get your breakthrough it feels fantastic.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												The Witness is an incredible puzzle game.  each puzzle is fair - it's not like myst or monkey island, where you might have to do something unorthodox, like combine a monkey and a wrench to get a "monkey wrench".  this game eshews the concept of an inventory in favour of having each puzzle represented as a glowing maze panel.  in doing so, The Witness removes all ambiguity between what *is* and what *isn't* a puzzle, which was a really smart design choice.this game was designed and iterated upon for nearly 10 years after the release of Braid, the developer's previous game, and the amount of polish and attention to detail in the island is, quite frankly, astonishing.  the island is dense, packed with puzzles, shortcuts between areas, and gorgeous views; it's one of the most engaging worlds i've explored in a game, right up there with Dark Souls.  one aspect of the world design that i was not fond of, however, were the audio logs scattered throughout the island.  they don't explain the plot of the game, but are rather a collection of miscellaneous, thematic quotes from famous philosophers and mathematicians.  these audio logs feel a little pretentious, and very superfluous (it's a tight, polished puzzle game, but it has audio logs arbitrarily tacked on).i have a few other minor gripes about the game, including the lack of a conclusive ending, but this isn't a game i played for its plot.  over the course of my first playthrough, i had countless "a-ha!" moments, which is a benchmark for any puzzle game.  The Witness is so rewarding and well-designed that the game's few flaws can be easily overlooked.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												The Witness is a fantastic puzzle game with a beautiful world to explore. While the only puzzle mechanic is, more or less, about connecting lines and dots, it does this in a wide variety of ways, from special rules, mirroring lines, and more. After the first couple dozen puzzles, the environment begins to have an effect on them, whether by being part of the puzzle itself from shadows, or from outside objects changing how a puzzle needs to be solved, or preventing it from being solved until later.The game has its flaws, though. There is no story to guide you, no outright given reason why you are here. This is a detriment to some folks, which I can understand. There are little hints, bits of audio, other things you can find, and there is apparently an underlying story and reason if you dig deep enough. But, as I said, without it being presented up front, that may or may not be an issue to you.The negative reaction of "It's only line puzzles stuck on panels!" is, to me, slightly silly. Yes, it's only line puzzles, but they get complex and interesting, and keep ramping that up with new rules the more puzzles you find. And its hard not to spoil things, but I will say that there are puzzles outside of thense 'panels'.Another negative is this game does not hold your hand. It does not explain how a puzzle mechanic works outside of a set of 'tutorial' panels for each one, which are scattered around with the other puzzle panels. You may be able to discern what the rules are for a certain puzzle piece, though. Sometimes you might not know if a puzzle is actually solvable without changing the environment somehow via a different puzzle. These can make it frustrating, but a good solution is if you can't solve a puzzle after a bit, move on for now and come back.The last issue is something I see a bunch of negative reviews and comments on here and elsewhere : That people were expecting Myst becuase thats what it kind of looked like, but didn't get Myst. That's a fairly big aspiration for a game, but don't pass off on a game because it wasn't what you were expecting it to be.So, summing it up : PROS : Lots of puzzles. Beautiful world. Interesting mechanics.CONS : Puzzles based off the same Line type. Very little story drive. Limited graphics options.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												There's a lot to cover so we'll dive right in;This is one of the worst puzzle games I have ever had the displeasure of playing.The effort is here, it is all here.  Every element for success has been tucked into the product, every bit of potential is bursting at the seems, and so it becomes the most insulting, most disappointing, most infuriating thing to see every single one of those aspects fail over, and over, and over, and over again.It is hard to summize everything wrong with The Witness, and almost impossible to do so in a short period, so if you just want a brief summary, it is as follows; there is no original writing, the visuals are fine, there's no music, the puzzles range from fantastic to utter garbage, and the two endings I've gotten thus far are some of the most pretentious, boring crap I've sat through in a long time.   Everything the Witness does, a game like Talos Principle will do better, so save yourself time and money and buy that instead.----------A breakdown;BAD PUZZLES:The puzzles are simple in theory, difficult in practice as any good puzzle game should be.  You click a circle, draw a line, and connect that line to the 'end' of the area.  This can be anything from a straight line to an entire maze.  This works on paper, and could even work in practice, were it not for the fact that it becomes tedious within the first hour or two.  Puzzles begin to include symbols and icons that change the rules of the individual mazes, and infuriatingly, these rules are not immediately explained.  Natural puzzle progression from good games in the genre will introduce a concept, make it more difficult, expand on it, and then incorporate it into larger concepts.  The Witness tries to do something similar, but will hide the tutorials in far removed areas of the island.  You will walk by puzzles with unknown, unexplained symbols twenty, thirty, FIFTY times before finding the area that explains how they work.  This non-linearity is not a point in the game's favor, as frustration will inevitably cause players to brute-force puzzles and work out at least some aspects of them before being TAUGHT.What is worse, and what some have mind-bogglingly listed as POSITIVE of this title, some puzzles will force you to rely entirely on the environment to solve, with no indication or hint as to what they want from you.  You may need to leave the immediate area, stand on a raised platform and notice the shadows mark out a rough path.  You may need to stand behind a specific area of a specific tree and line up the branches to show where you can't go on a maze.  You may need to line up SEVERAL branches, see if those are the branches the game wants, fail, and then try another set.  Over and over and over.  It is not so much being presented with a 100-piece jigsaw puzzle and being asked to solve it, but being presented with a 100-piece puzzle that only has 99 pieces, and being mocked when you didn't realize the last piece was being hidden under a newspaper in the corner of the room.  LAZY WRITING:The writing and dialogue is highly interesting, highly thought-provoking, and highly engrossing as you find collectibles all over the map.  The problem is that NONE OF IT is original writing!  Every scrap of it is ripped directly from lectures, quotations and speeches made from all across human history, and while almost all of it is incredibly interesting to listen to, you can't give a point to the game for it when all of it is also accessible from Google.  The developers and designers have not even attempted to put their own spin or perspective on the issues they are putting forth, instead drowning the player in sourced quotations from folk like Einstein.  BAD PUZZLE COLLECTIBLES:On top of the interesting collectibles in the form of small data-sticks or videos, there are also the much more boring collectibles in the form off hidden mazes.  These are puzzles that are hidden in the environment themselves, forcing you to line up a balloon-and-string, for example, to form the circle and line that you then trace down and complete.  The issue here is that they rarely are ever actually PUZZLES; the difficulty is in finding the markings in the sand or rocks, or standing in the right place to see the metal girder match up with the stone wall.  Once you find it, it takes half a second to complete, and then off you go searching for another and there are DOZENS of these in the world. LACK OF MUSIC:There is no music, and the only sound is that of your footsteps and the occasional ambiance.  The developers used if memory serves something like 10,000 footstep sound samples for the game, and while I adore that kind of dedication and wish it was used more, I was desperately wishing at times for some actual background music while I stared blankly at a puzzle I'd been stuck on for 20 minutes.  INSULTING FINAL LEVEL:The longer I played, the more irritated and frustrated I became with the poor design choices.  I will admit freely to using a guide at times and, by the final 'level', almost exclusively, because I became so tired with the cheap and childish tactics that I simply couldn't bring myself to care any longer.  Not only do you have to deal with puzzles not providing you with enough information to be solved, not only do you have to deal with trying to find where you should stand before you CAN solve certain puzzles, or if this is one of those puzzles you need to be somewhere else and that's the reason you cannot complete it, but by the final area, it genuinely feels as if the developers threw their hands up and stopped trying.Where in most puzzle game, and good games period, the final areas are a compilation of all the tests and challenges you've faced, where you have to rely on the accumulation of your knowledge from time spent with the game, the final areas of the Witness simply couldn't be bothered.  Instead of becoming more difficult, they instead resort to pathetic, childish distractions.  Instead of solving a difficult puzzle, you have to solve a moderately-difficult puzzle while your screen flashes at you in distraction.  Or while the colors invert, or while the puzzle itself spins uncontrollably and you have to fight the controls to do what you want.  Even elsewhere in the game this is present, making you feel frustrated not because you are failing a logic puzzle, but because you can't control your mouse properly even after you know the solution.BAD ENDINGS:And to top it all off, the endings are garbage.  Pretentious, monotonous, BORING garbage.  Without spoiling specifics or location, one ending even has the audacity to fly you in near silence through the map you have just spent 15+ hours completing, showing as it erases all your progress and resets all the puzzles and work you have done.  FINAL THOUGHTS:If you have read through this entire review, it should be clear that nobody who loathes a game would spend this much time writing about it.  I wanted, DESPERATELY wanted to enjoy this game, and the fact I spent more than 15 hours on a single run should prove that.  But every design decision fails, the mixing of good-with-bad puzzles leaves you frustrated and without the glorious "AH-HA!" moment you reach when solving a difficult challenge, the graphics are good, the story is lazy, the soundtrack is nonexistent, and every single thing this game does, the Talos Principle (which was released over a year or more before this) does better.  It is incredibly disappointing to see so much effort and talent go into a product that, ultimately, comes out as a 4.5/10, average or slightly worse than average, title.  Even after spending only 2$, roughly, on this product in a humble-bundle, I would advise any potential buyers to steer clear and spend their money elsewhere.+Visuals+Atmosphere-Gameplay-Sound-Puzzles-Story-Endings-Difficulty4.5/10

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												This review contains no spoilers.Warning: I would be very cautious about reading other reviews and being robbed of some of the best experiences the game has to offer.The Witness is hands down the best puzzle game I have ever played.The bite-sized puzzles never feel too imposing - you just about never look at a puzzle and think "I don't think I'm up for that. I think I'll come back to it tomorrow.".The essence of the gameplay is the combination of those basic logic puzzles (the fundamental concepts of the puzzle boards) and a huge variety of environmental complications like colored panes of glass and tree limbs and erased lines and more. No other game mixes environmental puzzles and symbolic logic puzzles together so masterfully.Another consequence of this unifying concept of the puzzle board is that you always know when you're looking at one. The game almost entirely lacks that Myst situation where you're wandering around unsure of where the next puzzle is. It also lacks the Myst problem of puzzles that are available, but impossible to solve until some other puzzle is solved first.The method of teaching the "rules" of the symbols on the puzzle boards through carefully designed challenges without ever using any explicit explanation is downright brilliant. They're carefully designed to make you think you understand a rule, to give you a series of puzzles where the rule you've come up with will work, but then to suddenly confront you with a puzzle where you have to rethink. You'll frequently discover that you convinced yourself something was impossible without ever seeing evidence of that.And none of the puzzles ever require guess-and-check.If you're guessing and checking, you're making a mistake. You can play Sudoku by guessing numbers and seeing how far they get you - you'll eventually solve any Sudoku puzzle that way - but you're not really playing Sudoku if you do that. So it is with The Witness.Once you understand all the pieces of the puzzle, it is always possible to solve it completely deductively. Learning the different ways to do this is a huge part of the game. Many complaints about the game center around the idea that the reviewer "learned all the rules" and then just spent hours and hours boringly brute-forcing puzzles. Learning the "rules" is just the start. The bulk of the game is not spent learning the rules, but learning the logical consequences of the rules that allow you to deductively solve puzzles. It isn't just about learning the rules of the dots, it's about learning that the rules of the dots imply that certain configurations are impossible. After you learn the rules, the subsequent boards will be about teaching you these implications.The audio logs and videos can feel a bit preachy at times, but having listened to all of them now, I understand a lot beter what purpose they served. They can initially come across as a pretentious affectation, like some college student going around spouting random philosophy quotes to seem "deep", but in time I think the game does actually reveal a fairly legitimate depth to what it's trying to express.And the final challenge, past the "end" of the game, is downright beautiful. While opinions may differ, I also found the reward for completing it to be far more worthwhile than the final rewards in most other games.Fundamentally though, The Witness is a game about changes in perception. It's a game about looking at something again and again and then suddenly and very viscerally seeing it in a totally different light. Sometimes that's puzzles - sometimes it's re-examining how you think a symbol works or how you reason about a certain kind of puzzle. Other times the shift in perspective is more profound.Penultimate warning: You will almost certainly want some paper and a pen. Maybe even some scissors.Final warning: If you use a guide to get through much of the game, there is a very real possibility, thanks to a brilliant pieces of design near the end, that you will find yourself unable to complete it.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												The Witness is the Dark Souls of puzzle games. Incredibly brutal, yet never unfair. If you are willing to learn from your mistakes, from your surroundings, from the deepest recesses of your brain without losing it, you will be able to do everything in this game. It's just a matter of learning, exploration and discovery.Do me a favour. Don't look at a guide unless you've gone away, tried to do other things, and thought about it for considerable time. There are things you won't understand straight away - this is because you haven't gathered the necessary information yet. And if you are forced to look up an answer, make sure to find out WHY. Because if you don't understand puzzle A yet, you probably won't understand puzzle B either.You can "finish" this game (achievement one) without ever really uncovering the plot (achievement two). Yes, there is a plot, and you will smash your head in trying to piece it together. :P But it's worth it, trust me. I did NOT see it coming.

content:

												This is one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It is not an adventure puzzler, it is a pure puzzle game - and it pulls that off perfectly. People complain you "only draw lines on squares", but that's like saying "you only shoot portals on walls" (Portal/Portal 2) or "you only hit a ball into a hole" (Golf), or "you only shoot enemies." (Every FPS in existence). The puzzles evolve using the same basic mechanic. Without words or instructions it guides you through every nuance of each mechanic.The feeling of a puzzle clicking in your mind after being stuck in this game is one of the best feelings a game has ever given me. I found myself smiling in pride after many puzzles. Understand what this game is and isn't before you buy it. But understand that it's one of the best pure puzzle experiences I've ever had the pleasure of playing.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												The Witness for me has been a presentation in opposites - beautiful and ugly, graceful and clumsy, plain-spoken and pompous. I wish I could give this game a rating between thumbs-up and thumbs-down, but since that's not possible, I'm going to have to choose not to recommend this game, despite the fact that there are many things about it I really like.The game places you on an island, and the way to move forward is to solve various puzzles throughout the island, which all have different rules and different levels of difficulty. Most of these puzzles take place on flat-panel screens, and involve using a cursor to draw on the panels and solve the puzzles by obeying the varous rules, like keeping blocks of a certain color together or blocking out specific tetris-like shapes. First, the quick pros and cons: +Island is beautiful, at least in terms of color palette and geometry.+Seems to run fairly well.+Puzzle rules are very clever, and you will feel smart when you figure out the hard ones.+Teaches you the rules organically, you learn the rules naturally most of the time.-Island is pretty, but there isn't much to actually do on it, other than interact with panel puzzles. Invisible walls are everywhere and it ends up feeling like a pretty-looking, but ultimately shallow façade.-Puzzle difficulty ramps up quickly, a bit too quickly sometimes. Prepare to be frustrated.-Story is so threadbare it might as well not exist. Bits and pieces are around, but nothing is ever explained, which along with the non-interactive island makes the setting feel even more pointless.-no musical score.-Some puzzles feel downright cheap. I'm not sure how people with vision/hearing problems will even complete this game.-Puzzles are presented in the most repetitious, boring way possible. In summary.... At first glance, The Witness appears to have a lot of things going for it, but when you spend some time with it you find out that all it really has to fall back on are the puzzles themselves. The problem with this is that the puzzles are presented to you in such a monotonous fashion that by the endgame I was getting pretty bored. Combine this with the non-existent story and un-interactive setting, and this feels like a "game" I could play on a piece of paper.Jon Blow wants to make games for smart people and I get that, but there is a difference between not suffering fools and spitting on them. It's been a while since I've played a game that felt so hostile to the player. Some of the stuff the game pulls near the end feels less like an intellectual challenge and more like a big middle finger.If you are a puzzle junkie AND you are good at them, you will probably enjoy this game. If not, look elsewhere.

Posted: April 23, 2016
												This game is so good I couldn't keep myself away from it for too long!The atmosphere is amazing. I love the colour palettes the developers chose, and the way there is so much happening on this fairly small island. They packed so much stuff in there! It looks so meticulously designed!The puzzles are quite well thought out. It takes this kind of path tracing puzzle concept and runs with it; it goes through many different rule sets all based on this one type of puzzle. The way in which it is done is awe-inspiring. I found myself excited whenever I figured out what one of those variations was.The game definitely lived up to the promise of a challenge - nothing was given for free (or at least, not much). However, as a puzzle game fan (and adventure game fan) myself, I found that to be quite entertaining. I was often faced with a puzzle that I at first thought was impossible. However, in every case, I would come around to the answer. It was really cool how they managed to get the puzzle's rule set accross without actually saying anything. I love games that give me these mental exercises without holding my hand, but still make it just enough of a challenge to be solvable without breaking your brain.The only drawback with the game (and it isn't a big one at all), is that some of the clips you find on the island are a little long. They vary from 10 minutes to more than an hour. Thankfully, though, there aren't that many to find. If you play this game, you'll know why I know about the lengths... ;) The videos overall (mixed with the audio clips strewn about the landscape) give you an interesting mix of perspectives on the human condition. However, I do feel that while they don't exactly fit within the context of this game, they do provide food for thought.In short, I would recommend this game to any puzzle or adventure game fan out there. As some have mentioned, there isn't much of a story, but I really don't care. It gives just enough to be mysterious, and that's enough for me.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Spoilers: I have 100% completed this game.  Then I went to bed.  When I woke up I found myself asking a few questions about it.  First, did I enjoy the experience while playing it?  Yes.  I enjoy a good puzzle and this game offered plenty of them.  They varied in difficulty and strategy and combined in interesting and creative ways.  I relished the "Ah-Ha" moments of finally solving a puzzle that had been stumping you for 10 minutes.  It was a well realized and truly enjoyable experience.  Second, would I play this game again?  No.  The primary issue of this game is that once it is learned then no challenge remains.  This is hardly a unique criticism of a puzzle game as the same can be said of Myst and it is still held up as a classic, but it does degrade the overall joy the game can bring me.  I have found that the best games are ones that can be played over and over for years bringing something new each time.  Unfortunately this game can not offer that.  Third, what did it all mean?  On this I am unsure.  If we are to take it at face value as a puzzle game then it holds up well for the reasons given above.  This does however raise an issue.  If the game is really about just solving puzzles then the only plot and story we are given is philosophical readings then why bother to include it those readings at all?  The Witness quickly teaches you that nothing is arbitrary.  If something is shaped in a strange or odd way, then it is a puzzle.  The game, from the onset, demonstrates that it is not haphazardly constructed and that all of the minute things that are included are deeply necessary for some reason that may not yet be clear.  It shows you that if you just dig deeper you can find the answer; you can solve the puzzle.  From this core concept of the game we must conclude that the philosophical readings have a function, a purpose, in the larger game.  Unfortunately, that is the flaw in this experience.  No plot resolution is given.  (Yes even with both endings.)  Saying "It was all a dream, or a simulation" doesn't inform the philosophy discussed.  It doesn't illuminate the goals or purpose of the people whose voices we have heard.  Who are they?  What are they doing?  Why should we care?  The game spends its entire span showing you that answers will come to those persistent and clever enough to find them.  Then it changes the rules with 10 seconds left on the clock and unfortunately declares: None of that Matters.  It wasn't real.  This is a critical mishandling of an otherwise perfect setup.  I can and have thought of literally 10 better endings since I started writing this.  Sadly this game falls woefully short in that respect.  With that said, perhaps overly harshly, I still did truly enjoy the game as I played it and I will recommend it to friends.  Unfortunately, I will be recommending it as a puzzle solving game.  Just a puzzle solving game.  This had the potential to be so much more.  There is perhaps nothing so tragic as a wasted opportunity.

												Really one of the best games I've played in ages. I'm not generally a fan of puzzle games. In fact, this game, Portal, and The Talos Principle are probably the only puzzle games I've finished. But this game just hooked me in and made me constantly want more. By taking away the constant stream of rewards that we're used to in modern games, it initially left me feeling a little cast off. I wasn't sure how I was supposed to play through a game if they weren't going to pull me through it, but once I started taking satisfaction in the completion of these truly mind-bending puzzles, I found myself absolutely enraptured. This is an experience I wish I could have again, and am so incredibly happy that the Witness turned out how Jonathan Blow wanted it to.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												If you like puzzles, this is your game, end of story. If not, it's not your game. I am surprised by some of the negative remarks.People say there's too much of the same puzzle. Well, you bought a puzzle game, so that's astute of you to notice. And if you think the puzzles never change, then you quit after 5 minutes. There is only one type of puzzle, but it's a deliberate choice. This game uses one basic method of interaction - find a path through a maze - and layers different rulesets on top of it. Some of the later puzzles are nothing short of meta, where your solution will end up represented in the "real world," or you will have to solve mazes on top of each other. Really, the game takes one idea and does it perfect, taking it as far as it can go. I personally dislike when games try to have "variety" but only end up doing 5,000 thing mediocre. If you want something else, buy something else and quit whining.People also say it's pretentious. Well, it's Jonathan Blow. What did you expect? I honestly didn't find the game itself pretentious, but the audio logs and videos you find throughout the game certainly are. But hey, you don't *have* to watch/listen to any of them, so if you dislike that kind of thing, no harm, no foul.People also say the ending is terrible. Well, there's no way to say this without spoilers... but you didn't actually find the ending!People also say it's too much money. I sympathize with that because $40 is sometimes a person's entire games budget for a month, or season, or even year. Just wait until it goes on sale. Whatever you do, DON'T pirate it. Don't be that guy. You think you're sending the message to Jonathan Blow that he needs to reduce the price, but the real message you send (and the one he got) is that he should put DRM on his next game. Don't. Just wait until a sale. I think it is worth the $40, though, so if you are able to spend that kind of cash and you like puzzle games you have no excuse.People also say it has no replay value. This makes sense because I never played Myst or Riven again after I beat them once. Oh wait that was sarcasm.Just buy the damn thing

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												The Witness is quite a weird and unique game. You find yourself on a beautiful island painted with radiant colours and filled with line puzzles. The environment is quite captivating and just wondering around is a pleasure in itself. The main strength of the game, though, lies in puzzles.I generally like puzzles and challenges so when I discovered this game along with statements like "it's really hard to complete", I instantely knew that I have to buy it. I can say now with certainty that it was the right choice. I really love the way the game teaches you how to solve puzzles. You start by easier ones and once you figured out the logic behind them you move onto the more complicated ones. It really feels like the game talks to you and I have never experienced anything quite like that in a game before. Sometimes it takes a long time to solve a puzzle and some people complain that even though you solve a really hard puzzle, you won't get a proper reward, but for me, personally, every puzzle I've completed felt like an accomplishment and I didn't really need any other rewards. When a hard puzzle opened up a way to even a harder puzzle, I usually just yelled "Bring it on!" at the scrreen. (Maybe I'm a masochist??) I am proud that I managed to complete the game without any walkthrough and that I solved the "red door" puzzle in the shipwreck not by brute-force but by actually understanding the puzzle. I promise you, there is a logic behind all the puzzles, nothing is random. If you are clueless on how to solve one, just look somewhere else and come back once you've learned the principle (or try to focus more on your environment). Mechanisms behind some of the puzzles were so brilliant I had to laugh. (Maybe I'm mad??)Seriously, if you like puzzles, just buy this game! If you don't like puzzles, I'm not sure why you're even looking at it. Buying it just because of the visuals is probably not worth it. Honestly, the "hidden/nonexistent" storyline in the game was too abstract for me. I listened to all the voice messages and watched all the videos and some of them are quite interesting and worth thinking about, but overall it didn't make much sense. The game is most likely intended as "open for interpretation," but I didn't get any clear message out of it except for some hints that making of the game was a pain. I feel like the story aspect could have been done better. Nevertheless, it didn't bother me very much and I would still recommend you to buy this game! I enjoyed it very much.

content:
Posted: February 3
												A mix of positive and negative. I cannot really recommend it, and under no circumstances should you even consider this game if you have any visual or audio impairment, whether in your computer or your head. The game will require things that are physically impossible for you and not even explain that.When it works, it works, and when it doesn't, you Google and probably find that you were wasting your time because you needed to solve some other puzzles before this one had enough information/pieces/whatever. If that sounds fun, this is for you.Puzzles do not explain their rules, so you are stuck with trial and error to find what this puzzle wants. Except that maybe there were a series of introductory puzzles for this rule type, but you happened to walk into an advanced puzzle before a basic one and nothing explained that the rules changed. "What do you want from me?!" If that sounds fun, this is for you.Half the puzzle is finding the puzzles. Some need a chain of other puzzles or precise placement. Some need to be activated in a long series of steps, so make sure to backtrack and see if finishing puzzles A, C, D, E, F, and K opened B.Not friendly to visual impairments. Some things look like logic puzzles but are instead puzzles of "can you walk to the right spot and turn at the right angle to find a visual effect that just gives you the answer?" Once you have that down, you get multiple steps, like (1) find the puzzle, (2) activate it, (3) find the right angle for part a, (4) find the switch to change the puzzle's angle, (5) find the right angle for part b, (6) maybe repeat those steps for a few letters, and (7) put it together and answer (from the right spot) (from the right angle). That probably sounds fun to some folks, so this is for you. I am told it does the same for audio impairments later; I have not gotten that far.This may be surprising for some players or developers, but there is a range of human visual function and memory. Some people cannot see some colors. If a puzzle requires color vision, the game is over for those players at that point, and they will not even see why until they Google it. Some people have literally no visual memory or ability to picture things in their heads. If a puzzle requires combining multiple visuals, that could be surmountable with screenshots. And so on with other perception difficulties.I am going to play a bit further in search of epiphanies, but the mix of "figure out the rules, we won't tell you" and "sometimes the rule is neurologically unlikely for you to even perceive" is bad for me, like giving a game requiring pixel-perfect placement to someone with Parkinson's.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												This might be the most polarizing game experience of my life... On one hand, The Witness is both beautiful and brilliant from an artistic and design sense. The lighting, materials and rendering are pure eye candy. The entire island integrates perfectly to form a continuous chain of incredibly intelligent puzzles. On the other hand, The Witness is also one of the most boring, poorly paced and non sensical games I have ever played. The story is told through audio logs which have no consitant theme and are mostly told out of context. While the rendering is great, the envirronment itself is bland comprised mostly of generic trees, rocks, cave walls, brick walls, wood planks, etc. Almost nothing has character in this world. The vast majority of the puzzles consist of standing in front of a grid and drawing lines to separate different icons. This gets very old and repetitive. Regardless of the low entertainment value, I have to reccomend this game beacuse it is just too inteligently designed to pass up. There are a lot of great ideas here.  Everyone should witness at least the first few hours of brilliance before the repetitive bordem sets in.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												The Witness pushes the envelope and demonstrates what can be done with video games as an artistic canvas. It succeeds on every level, graphics and game play are both outstanding, but structurally this is peerless. It is not only the antithesis of modern gaming trends but an achievement that transcends the medium. For the first time we have a game that can stand along side the best offerings from the worlds of cinema and literature. It is beautiful, deep, mysteroius and meaningful in ways that make all other games seem simplistic and shallow. I know that even the game's most ardent fans have said that this is not a game for everyone, but please, please try it. There are many who won't fancy The Witness who will then play it and find themselves drawn in to this amazing game. The beauty, the detail and the variety of the island alone could probably justify the purchase. It wont take long before you realize the genius and the depth of The Witness and many, like myself, will conclude that this is a masterpiece and the best video game yet made.

Some people have literally no visual memory or ability to picture things in their heads. If a puzzle requires combining multiple visuals, that could be surmountable with screenshots. And so on with other perception difficulties.I am going to play a bit further in search of epiphanies, but the mix of "figure out the rules, we won't tell you" and "sometimes the rule is neurologically unlikely for you to even perceive" is bad for me, like giving a game requiring pixel-perfect placement to someone with Parkinson's.

												This might be the most polarizing game experience of my life... On one hand, The Witness is both beautiful and brilliant from an artistic and design sense. The lighting, materials and rendering are pure eye candy. The entire island integrates perfectly to form a continuous chain of incredibly intelligent puzzles. On the other hand, The Witness is also one of the most boring, poorly paced and non sensical games I have ever played. The story is told through audio logs which have no consitant theme and are mostly told out of context. While the rendering is great, the envirronment itself is bland comprised mostly of generic trees, rocks, cave walls, brick walls, wood planks, etc. Almost nothing has character in this world. The vast majority of the puzzles consist of standing in front of a grid and drawing lines to separate different icons. This gets very old and repetitive. Regardless of the low entertainment value, I have to reccomend this game beacuse it is just too inteligently designed to pass up. There are a lot of great ideas here.  Everyone should witness at least the first few hours of brilliance before the repetitive bordem sets in.

												Got the game from the "Humble Monthly", I really enjoyed The Talos Principle and thought I'd give this game a go.Played 15 hours approx, had some fun, overall feeling somewhat disappointed.Liked:-Nice aesthetics (Probably the best feature of the game)-Learning the puzzle mechanics was fun-Astonished how far they could stretch the "drag a path to the end" basic puzzle designDisliked:-Finding the "Puzzle rules tutorials" is annoying since there's no indication anywhere where they are, you basically have to run around hoping you run into them.-Gets really repetitive once you figure out all the "puzzle rules"-Sometimes it feels like the game throws you to the hard puzzles too quickly (Blue tetris blocks really come to mind)-I'm tone deaf and the sound based puzzles felt like I was being cheated.-The whole end game (mountain) puzzles felt like a "♥♥♥♥ you" to my face, especially the ending itself.-Movement speed is really slow compared to how big the map is-Some areas require you to solve the same puzzle several times to move between them, and then wait as the slowest mechanics ever move your platform to the other area, and then you realize in order to get back you have to do that again. -Don't know if the boat was supposed to be a "fast travel", since it's so slow (even at full throttle) it's better to just walk to where you want to go.-Often the game felt like it's being annoying on purpose, either forcing you to take screenshots, travel a long corridor only to have nothing on the other side (Closed door most likely), or the audio logs being so tiny I only realized they were a thing halfway through the game. -Audio logs felt pretentious and detached from the game, maybe there's a "true ending" that makes sense of them but honestly I'm not interested enough to figure it out.

content:
Posted: March 29
												Starting The Witness I hoped for a good game – I loved Antichamber, Portal and Talos Principle and I was hoping for something similar. I was disappointed. There’s no story in the game and no introduction to puzzle solving mechanics. It wouldn’t be much of a problem if mechanics stayed consistent. Unfortunately once functioning of puzzle mechanics is discovered than there’s no guarantee that game won’t change the rules all of sudden which it does! It ruins the experience. It’s just like someone said “Oh, you just spent 20 minutes discovering how the puzzle work? Let’s change the rules completely! I don’t care if the puzzle looks almost the same like before. Figure new way out of this”. What’s more a lot of riddles depends not on your logical skills but on being observant paying attention to the environment. All in all everything comes to try & error mechanic which I just hate. It’s illogical. You’re just hoping to think like an author of puzzles instead of actually using your brain. I mean, good puzzles are based on some logical fundaments. If you’re creating riddle intended to solve, you can’t think of everything you want. You need to base your thoughts on some logical background or leave some clues of your thought process. Without it you can create the most ridiculous enigmas which actually can never be solved. Or rather surely, some people given enough time will solve it, but it’ll never be as rewarding as actually figuring things out based on things I mentioned. Even though I figured out some of the puzzles I couldn’t help the feeling that’s all of it is pointless. If there was a bit of mystery and story behind the game than maybe I could be dragged in. Instead we get a game which ultimately is a set of riddles – nothing more. Once you finish some of it you just loose the appetite for more. Game had the potential. Pity it wasn’t used.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												The Witness pushes the envelope and demonstrates what can be done with video games as an artistic canvas. It succeeds on every level, graphics and game play are both outstanding, but structurally this is peerless. It is not only the antithesis of modern gaming trends but an achievement that transcends the medium. For the first time we have a game that can stand along side the best offerings from the worlds of cinema and literature. It is beautiful, deep, mysteroius and meaningful in ways that make all other games seem simplistic and shallow. I know that even the game's most ardent fans have said that this is not a game for everyone, but please, please try it. There are many who won't fancy The Witness who will then play it and find themselves drawn in to this amazing game. The beauty, the detail and the variety of the island alone could probably justify the purchase. It wont take long before you realize the genius and the depth of The Witness and many, like myself, will conclude that this is a masterpiece and the best video game yet made.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I am at a loss for what to say in reviewing this game.  While it has all the elements that are required to define it as a video game, I find it difficult to simply lump it into that category which, on the whole, contains so very many things that are so dissimilar to The Witness as to bear virtually no resemblance to it.  A technical manual for operating an industrial machine, a government report on options to boost supply chain efficiency, a bodice-ripper novella, the Bible - these are all books.  What clarity of understanding is gained by lumping them all together, as though all books were basically the same kind of thing?This is the problem (at least, the reviewing problem) I have when it comes to say anything about The Witness.  It is an artefact that has been made in a specific way to be interacted with in order to provide you an experience.  I could try to review this game, but the game itself is not what I would actually be talking about.  Anything that I might try to tell you that would explain why I love this game would ultimately be about me and my experiences, and it would only be about The Witness in the most indirect and unhelpful way, for you.The Witness has made me feel very uncomfortable.  It has shaken me.  It has elated me.  It has brought me into the light of new understanding about basic elements of my existence, and my way of relating to it and the existence of others.  I feel a renewed capacity for awe; the world and my self are more glorious and more terrible for it.  I am more, and less, than when I began The Witness.  Long after I no longer launch the executable, I will still be "playing" this "game".  I approached it openly, made a place for it within me, and invited it in.  The most important part of this game is not taking place on the computer or the screen, but within the player.  I cannot say whether this game will be worth anything to you, because more than any other thing of this kind I have ever interacted with, the experiences this game produces depends on the player.Yet, in spite of this, I am compelled to recommend it to you.  Don't look anything up online.  Don't read anything else.  Just start the game, and pay attention.  Think about where you are and what you are doing.  Perhaps you will not find anything like what I did.  But I would say that you owe it to yourself to try, as what I found were experiences that expanded and enriched my humanity - and that I desperately wish every person could have.

												The Witness is about exploration and puzzles. Solutions to puzzles allow you to explore new areas, and exploration of areas allows you to learn rules to solve puzzles. content:
Posted: April 16
												This was good! If you're on this page then you probably have heard a general summary of how this game works. If that sounds at all like "your kind of game", then you will probably be very happy with The Witness, as its execution on indie-puzzle-FPS-exploration is top notch, and there's really never been another game quite like it. It's kind of like a "Metroidvania" game where you gain new abilities to reach new areas and defeat new challenges...except instead of your character gaining, like, new boots that let you jump higher, YOU, the player, learn things that let you access new areas and solve new puzzles you couldn't do before.  The whole thing is a lush learning experience with an entirely new type of brainteaser, like the first time you ever sat down with a crossword puzzle or a sudoku book.If you are not super into puzzles, probably not for you; it's not quite on the level of something like Portal, where it's going to convert folks into puzzle diehards who would never have been otherwise. But like I said, if the basic description sounds like your cup of tea, then you'll like it quite a lot.

content:
Posted: April 22
												Aaaah. It started so great. And it still is so great in many ways. This title is in the middle for me, but it leans slighlty more to a no recommendation. I hope that this review can make you deside better if this is for you or not. Don't take my review as the game is no good. It is a good game, but not for me, and hence I wouldn't recommend it. Read on!Ultimately it comes down to if you enjoy the game-mechanic or not, and if it has a satiesfying conclusion. Well, in my case, it doesn't, even if starts off well.Look, if you like serious, die-hard, puzzle-challenges and have loads of patience, this game is for you, and I will give it a great recommendation. The puzzle mechanic is interesting and eventuelly very challenging. But I feel the game gets lost in what it tries to tell. The premise doesn't hold up, and doesn't evolve well.The good:Well, I loved how it started. I really enjoyed "witnessing" everything around you, finding solutions and ways to see things in a new perspecive by simply looking a little deeper around you. I truly enjoyed finding patterns in the environment. The game also looks and sounds great. It is enjoyable to walk around taking in the sites. I almost felt it could be kind of a meditation practice just walking around, observing and solving fairly easy puzzles (in the beginning) if you simply take your time and look. There is a lot of puzzles, and lots of extras even after "completing" the game.The not so good:Well, perhaps I don't enjoy puzzle-games as much as another. But for me, the game just becomes too hard, too fast, AND the point of the game is lost: In the beginning a solution feels like "Oh, I got it, I see now, I understand!" and it relies on you observing around you, looking deeper. The later puzzles do not have the same "aha" moments and evolution like the way it started so beautifully, just more complications. It almost feels like the puzzles weren't challenging enough, so "complications" were added. For example, "follow line to end", but later "follow line to end while the puzzle is blurry and spinning". That doesn't feel clever, just annoying. It is like solving a math problem while your kid is jumping on you, screaming in your ear. You still know the solution, it is just harder to do, but for other reasons, not because the problem itself is interesting.For example, after a while (depending on how you traverse the island of course) you will start to encounter tetris symbols in the puzzles. No spoilers here, but they are not easy to solve. Because these puzzles depend on visualising the solution. And there is no clever solution or real "aha" moment here except a lot of mindbeding visualizations that take a while to solve, trust me. Sure, the easy ones are ok at first, but after a while the fun just stopped, dead. And then it got even worse.It feels like the initial mechanics are "observe", while the later mechanics are "visualize", and here is becomes really really tricky at times, especially if you are not so good at visualizing. And I feel the game loses its premise, where the "witnessing" is now happening inside your skull more than in the actual game. You don't need the surroundings in order to solve the puzzles at later stages. You need to be really good at visualizing the solutions. Yes, not all puzzles, but the ones with tetris symbols in them, or when the puzzle itself starts to "spin out of control".And there are so many puzzles, that you eventually tire, because each take a while to solve at later stages. Sure, if you like this, then this is a paradise of puzzles, litterally. But it is then more like doing hard sudoku (or similar) on the train. The puzzle is the only thing, not the surroundings. It doesn't matter what happens around you. What is the point of being on a beautiful island? None, and I think the game utilized this idea really well in the beginning, but not later on.I started to look up the solutions online. For one or two puzzles, this can happen to the best of us and no big deal, but for when you start to feel you have to look all of them up... The alternative was to sit and think and vizualize which took me out of the game completely, and like the above mentioned sudoko on the train example - I'm not in the game, I'm in my own head and the immersion is lost. Alternatively I could just try a solution randomly, but that is not that much fun either after a lot of tries. I don't feel like I am learning either like in the earlier puzzles. I also though what is the point in playing this game, looking up all the answers? Exactly. So, I did not finish this game. But got about 15 hours out of it. I still enjoyed 75% of that time.If you managed all by yourself to solve all these puzzles, I admire your wits AND your free time.I loved this game for the idea of exploring your surroundings and finding solutions. I hated it for bending my mind in half while different colors flashed in front of my eyes, puzzles started rotating, and those damn tetris puzzles....This game is a masterpiece in many ways no doubt, but a masterpiece where the message got lost and the mechanics became a pain.If you really want to try it, wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: February 22
												I don't think there is a good way to convey my opinions of this game. I generally very much enjoy puzzle games but I didn't really enjoy this one, I ended up finishing it out of feeling that I should instead of wanting to. The basic structuring of the game is that you draw lines, these lines vary quite a bit in what they need to accomplish though. You start out in a small tutorial area that only teaches you to draw a line and follow wires it doesn't explain at all that lines will need to function in 20 different ways through the entire game.The game is easy for the most part once you learn those 20 different line functions but the game never explains any of them to you. This is very frustrating when you first start the game and walk up to a puzzle that "You have to seperate these colored blocks from the three other colors while pairing those stars and making that shape and if you get it wrong you have to waste time doing the last puzzle again." This is an example of a puzzle intended to be done later in the game but that itself is another problem, the game doesn't provide any direction for you to follow so that you progress properly it gives you a pretty world that starts off very confusing. In most puzzle games I am generally against using guides but in this one due to the amount of puzzles and the obnoxiousness of having to repeat them if you fail I would actually encourage using a guide if you get stuck. However at the end of the game there are puzzles that are randomly generated as well and they can be unsolvable so a guide won't help here.While I didn't enjoy the gameplay and puzzle design I did really enjoy the general aesthetic of the game. The environments are very well designed and obviously had countless hours spent on making them perfect, this is apparent in how many hidden environmental puzzles there are thankfully they are entirely optional to complete or the game would be harder and about 6X longer.Overall I think the game might be worth buying for anyone who likes puzzle games but only around a $15 price point not $40. If you want a first person puzzle game The Talos Principle is much better.

content:
Posted: April 13
												Usually I really like puzzle games, even though ironically, I tend to suck at them. So given that people’s reactions to this game were so positive, I was quite anxious to see that this was part of the last Humble Monthly Bundle. Because I had a feeling that paying $40 for this game would be quite steep from what I’ve seen and heard, but at $1.50 I’ll certainly take a look.Having now played the game I can’t really say that I enjoyed myself for the bigger part of the experience. The developer may claim that this game has over 500 puzzles, but in reality, there are maybe a dozen repeated ad nauseam. Because the central mechanic is based around line-drawing puzzles that incorporate a variety of different rules you have to follow. Some are based on blocked paths, sometimes with the addition of a symmetrical line being drawn on the board so you have to keep track of two lines simultaneously. Some require you to divide the board up as indicated by Tetris shapes or by colored rectangles and suns and all of them have different rule that sometimes get combined. So in essence there are these few rules that apply spread out over hundreds of more or less identical panels. And it gets boring after a while.Now don’t get me wrong, the game does evoke a sense of wonder. Traversing the island, finding secret passages and making quick progress through the first couple of puzzles is interesting. But eventually, you’ll hit a roadblock. Because the rules are not properly explained at any point. You have to infer them through tutorial puzzles that are way too easy to accidentally solve or brute force your way through, that they hardly ensure you’ve actually understood the concepts they’re trying to teach you. And the fact that the island is open for exploration means that you’ll almost certainly wander into an area that uses rules from other parts of the island that you haven’t even encountered yet. Just take my word and ignore the town at the center of the island until you’ve done everything else, because you’ll be gnashing your teeth. With this lack of direction also comes a lack of narrative. The only payoff for solving these puzzles is opening up doors to even more puzzles. Sometimes you’ll find audiologs and they’re seldom of any use. If you’re lucky, you’ll find a room containing a hexagonal pattern that can be input at a certain point in the game for some videos that ostensibly have to do with what the game is about at its core. But honestly, the game does such a terrible job of informing the player both mechanically and narratively what it wants to be about that I simply couldn’t care less about the artsy fartsy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t it’s trying to communicate. Once you get the hang of it, the puzzles become entertaining again during the mid-game and if you keep your eyes open you’ll see environmental puzzles as well hidden literally in plain sight, right before your eyes and that revelation is really cool. However, it just drags on and on with puzzle after puzzle giving you no reward whatsoever. And the difficulty spikes between certain puzzles are insane. Sometimes you’ll be breezing through a handful of puzzles without breaking a sweat but every so often in confronts you with one that you can’t easily solve. And if you’re anything like me, in those situations, you’ll look up guides online to find the solutions because god damn it, I understood the mechanic, I just can’t be arsed to sit here with my thumb up my♥♥♥♥♥for 10 minutes trying to figure this♥♥♥♥♥♥out. And once you get to that stage, you’ll notice that none of the guides provide explanations on how they’ve reached the solutions. They’ll just give you screenshots of the correct lines you’ve got to draw, which made me want to choke each and every last one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. But that’s not the fault of the game.What is are the people the game will most certainly exclude from playing it. If you have any sort of color deficiency in your vision, just skip this game altogether, there’s no way you’ll be able to beat it on your own. The same goes if somethings wrong with your hearing, some puzzles rely heavily on what you’re able to hear. Speaking of which, for some utterly bizarre reason, there’s no music in this game. The only thing you’ll hear are your footsteps, a few environmental sounds and the aforementioned sound indicators for certain puzzles. In the end, I enjoyed certain sections of the game, no doubt about it. But it just goes on way too long with terrible tutorials and absolutely no payoff whatsoever. I didn’t 100% complete it, because ♥♥♥♥ that noise, but I’ve seen the secret ending on YouTube. Sure, it expands on the point the game has about seeing things from a different perspective, since that also what most of the game is about, but there’s no actual point being delivered, no argument made. It tries to sound deep and meaningful when it isn’t. And as such, I can’t recommend it, especially not at the ludicrous price they’re asking for. Get Antichamber instead, it also taxes your lateral thinking muscles way more gracefully than this with far more varied puzzles. It’s got the same amount of narrative as well but isn’t pretentious about itself and only costs $20, so there you go. Sorry Blow Johnny, didn’t like it as much as I did Braid.
